20649699|A list of 108 endemic taxa from Atlantic Central Africa occuring in Cameroon is given. Among these, 72 (67%) are epiphytes, 7 (6%) are facultative epiphytes and 29 (27%) are terrestrial. These figures may present important local variations: from lowland to montane forest, the proportion of epiphytes decreases with about 20%. Fourty three (40%) taxa are known only from Cameroon and the specific endemism for Orchidaceae in this country is ca. 8.8%. Two genera, Gastroida R.Br. and Ossiculum P.J.Cribb & Laan, are endemic to Cameroon. The species Polystachya bipoda Stvart, Ancistrorhynchus obovata Stvart inedit., Cyrtorchis submontana Stvart inedit., Tridactyle anthomoniaca (Rchb.f.) Summerh. subsp. nana P.J.Cribb & Stvart, Ancistrorhynchus crystalensis P.J.Cribb & Laan and Polystachya kubalae Szlach. & Olsz. are newly recorded for the flora of Cameroon. Twenty four taxa were not recorded in Cameroon by Szlachetko & Olszewski (1998, 2001a & 2001b), but were already cited in the literature as present in Cameroon. For each taxon, exhaustive or thorough literature is provided, as well as the distribution in Atlantic Central Africa, a list of specimens known from Cameroon and an assessment of the conservation status. According to IUCN criteria, 4% of the taxa are Least Concerned (LC), 29% are Critically Endangered (CR), 24% are Endangered (EN) and 35% are Vulnerable (VU).
20649700|Two analyses are carried out for a reconstruction of the phylogeny of the large angiosperm family Rubiaceae. The position of Luculia and Coptosapelta, unresolved or sister to all other Rubiaceae in most of the recently published results, is reanalysed by using five plastid and three nuclear DNA regions sequenced for selected Rubiaceae taxa. A supertree is constructed for more than 500 species in 300 genera, i.e. ca. 50% of the genera known in the family. The supertree is derived from four source trees based on rbcL, rps16, trnL-trnF and atpB-rbcL, the latter with 106 newly generated sequences. The results are confronted with the morphological, anatomical and biogeographical knowledge of the family and discussed in the light of other molecular phylogenies. It is proposed to recognize only two subfamilies, Cinchonoideae (raphides mostly absent; secondary pollen presentation common) and Rubioideae (raphides present; heterostyly common). Luculia and Coptosapelta are found to be basal to the rest of the Cinchonoideae, which are divided in two newly recognized supertribes, Ixoridinae and Cinchonidinae. Also in the subfamily Rubioideae, two major clades may be distinguished and are recognized as supertribes Psychotriidinae (predominantly woody) and Rubiidinae (predominantly herbaceous); the genus Colletoecema and the tribes Urophylleae, Ophiorrhizeae, Lasiantheae and Coussareeae are basal Rubioideae falling outside these two supertribes. Four alliances are spotted as groups for which major problems exist with regard to relationships and tribal delimitation: three neotropical groups, viz. the Calycophylleae/Condamineeae alliance, the Catesbaeeae/Chiococceae complex and the Rondeletieae alliance, and the pantropical Spermacoceae s.lat. The cladogenesis of Rubiaceae depicted by the supertree is strongly correlated with the present geographical distribution of taxa. The results are summarized in a conspectus of the family enumerating the tribes and listing all their genera for which the inclusion is corroborated by DNA sequences. Newly recognized tribes and subtribes are the Henriquezieae-Posoqueriinae, the Palicoureeae and the Rubieae-Theligoninae and -Kelloggiinae. Some tribes are reduced to subtribes, viz. Virectarieae (subtribe of Sabiceeae), Bertiereae (subtribe of Coffeeae) and Isertieae (subtribe of Cinchoneae). Novel positions are proposed for the genera Aulacocalyx, Calycosiphonia, Cremaspora, Crossopteryx and Morelia.

20649716|Mantalania longipedunculata De Block & A.P.Davis (Rubiaceae), was recently described from le Sainte Marie, Madagascar, based on a single collection in fruit. Due to the large-scale destruction of native forest on le Sainte Marie, the species was suspected of being critically endangered or even extinct. However, during a recent field trip to the type locality, M. longipedunculata was rediscovered. The species description is emended, particularly with regard to flower characters.
20649712|A new species of Bertiera (Rubiaceae) from Cameroon and Gabon, Bertiera heterophylla Nguembou & Sonk, is described and illustrated. This new species belongs to the subgenus Bertiera and appears to be closely related to Bertiera bicarpellata. Bertiera heterophylla differs from B. bicarpellata in having lateral branches with terminal inflorescences while on the main stem, the inflorescences are axillary.
20649708|This study is based on 598 phytosociological relevs and 1021 plant species taken during an extensive vegetation survey in the Republic of Benin. Site selection was primarily directed towards forest reserves to understand the potential vegetation patterns countrywide. Distributional patterns assessed by means of numerical analyses suggested a meaningful subdivision of Benin into ten phytogeographical districts (PDs). Chorological analysis proved to be valuable as a complementary approach to the characterisation of the phytosociologically-defined districts and allowed their merging into three major phytochorological zones, namely the Guineo-Congolian and Sudanian regions, linked by the Guineo/Sudanian transition zone. The phytogeographical patterns described were consistent with the hypothesis of water availability-driven variation in species and chorotype compositions. While the climate in terms of several climate elements was the primary factor, rainfall considered alone failed to explain the observed patterns. The biogeographical particularities of the PD Pob in southern Benin were elucidated by the exclusive presence of many Guineo-Congolian endemic genera. The PDs Bassila and Atacora Chain turned out to be of great ecological and biogeographical relevance within the Sudanian regional centre of endemism. Evidence is provided for a former floristic connection of these PDs to the West African Forest Blocks. The results show how the phytosociology approach through numerical analyses of a large dataset constitutes an effective methodological tool for clarifying phytogeographical patterns at meso-scale. Moreover, phytosociology and chorology appear as complementary approaches to phytogeography.

20649711|The effect of exotic tree species on the flora of their undergrowth was investigated in an afforested site of Sm in Benin. The main vegetation in the area consists of timber tree plantation and fallow. Widely distributed species were in the majority (68.8% of spectrum) compared to guineo-congolian species (16.9% of spectrum). These plantations were poor in indigenous species and housed an undergrowth quite different from the native flora surrounding the plantations. This impoverishment of the original floristic diversity was related to ecological effects (shallows, litter amount, soil acidity, competition, allelopathy, etc.) induced by exotic trees (Acacia auriculiformis, Acacia mangium, Casuarina equisetifolia and Eucalyptus camaldulensis). In the Acacia plantation, undergrowth was covered by Acacia pods, stems, phyllodes and a litter amount of 21.05 t MS/ha. The Casuarina equisetifolia plantations presented also a high amount of litter and low plant species richness in the undergrowth. Eucalyptus camaldulensis plantations negatively influenced flora diversity through soil acidification and allelopathy. Casuarina equisetifolia alone or in association with Acacia auriculiformis increased the floristic diversity of the undergrowth. /// Une tude d'impact des essences exotiques plantes en futaies sur la flore de leur sousbois a t effectue dans le primtre de reboisement de Sm au Bnin. 3668569|The 124 species of myxomycetes collected by the authors in the years 1999-2001 from the Hunan Province in Southern China are listed with three other species reported in the literature. Some information on their substrata and distribution is given.
3668558|Patterns of ecological succession have been demonstrated for decomposer communities, but the details of such patterns with respect to the role of eumycetozoans have not been addressed. Successional patterns can be inferred from a sequence of closely located sites which differ only in age, but are controlled for other sources of variation. Hawai'i, the largest and youngest of the Hawaiian Islands, offers an ideal site for such studies, consisting of variously-aged landforms underlain by similar substrates, and influenced by similar climates and biotic communities. Soil/litter samples were collected from nine montane mesic sites of similar elevation and rainfall, but ranging in substrate age from 67 to 10,000 ybp. Samples were processed to recover dictyostelid (cellular) slime molds according to established protocols. Results suggest that slightly different assemblages of dictyostelids occupy the soil/litter derived from different-aged parent materials. The density and species diversity of dictyostelids was higher in soil/litter samples from the youngest sites. The time necessary for dictyostelids to colonize a site is less than 67 years. It is hypothesized that colonization of the soil/litter by dictyostelids is followed by the arrival of predators, particularly nematodes, which adversely affect the density and species diversity of soil amoebae in general, and dictyostelids in particular.
3668561|Palm trees (Arecaceae) are specialized ecosystems which host a wide variety of organisms, including Myxomycetes. Copernicia prunifera (Miller) H.E. Moore (wax palm), Mauritia flexuosa L.f. (buriti palm) and Astrocaryum vulgare Mart. (tucum palm) were selected to study incidence, richness and species diversity of myxomycetes in savanna, riverine forest and secondary forest at Sete Cidades National Park (45-415 S and 4130-4140 W, 480 m alt., 6,221.48 ha), Piau State, northeastern Brazil. Fructifications were searched for on both dead and live trunks, leaves, spathes and inflorescences. The specimens are preserved in the Herbarium UFP (Department of Botany, Federal University of Pernambuco). Myxomycetes were found both in dry and rainy seasons, and the highest abundance and diversity of taxa were observed during the rainy period. A high incidence of myxomycetes (70-100%) was registered, with a diversity index of 5.23 (M. flexuosa), 4.25 (C. prunifera) and 5.05-2.94 (A. vulgare). The highest occurrence was registered on petiole, followed by leaf sheath, leaf blade and spathe, being rare on inflorescence and trunk. A total of seven families, sixteen genera, forty-four species and one variety was identified. The most frequent species were Arcyria cinerea (Bull.) Pers., A. denudata (L.) Wettst., Hemitrichia calyculata (Speg.) M.L.Farr, H. serpula (Scop.) Rostaf. ex Lister, Metatrichia vesparia (Batsch) Nann.-Bremek. ex G.W.Martin & Alexop., Physarum nucleatum Pers. and Stemonitis fusca Roth. Comments and geographical distribution of these species in Brazil are presented.
3668564|Nivicolous myxomycetes are an ecological group of species growing in alpine and subalpine regions of the world near to the melting snow. Extensive field work was done in the mountain areas of the Iberian Peninsula from 1991 to 2002 which demonstrates the richness and variety of the myxobiota in this Mediterranean region. Among the areas with optimum conditions of geography, climate and vegetation, 123 localities were sampled from ten mountain ranges. Almost 1500 field collections were made and a first list of 48 different species is presented here. The altitudinal distribution and phenology of the sporulation of these myxomycetes are analyzed. Working hypotheses on how abiotic factors can influence the development of nivicolous species and some adaptative characters of these species are also presented.
3668568|This study examines the diversity and ecology of myxomycetes on seven native tree species in Hunan Province, south-central China. All the trees are being cultivated within less strictly protected parts of Badagongshan National Nature Reserve and similar forest reserves. Community data were collected for epiphytic bryophytes and lichens and corticolous myxomycetes. The data on myxomycetes were acquired by cultivating bark samples in moist chambers. Over 80% of the 200 moist chambers yielded identifiable myxomycete specimens, representing 33 different taxa. There were clear differences in epiphyte community composition between the studied tree species. Non-metric multidimensional scaling (NMS) was used to produce graphical depictions of community relationships and habitat variables. The three tree species with neutral or slightly acid bark had similar epiphyte communities, while each of the other four species grouped separately. The main trend in myxomycete diversity contrasted with those of epiphytic bryophytes and lichens. Species richness of myxomycetes was highest on relatively acidic bark with a high water retention capacity, while the diversities of epiphytic bryophytes and lichens were highest on less acidic and relatively smooth bark. Data on epiphyte community composition can be used to develop simple and cost-effective methods for preserving biodiversity in local forestry. It can assist in the choice of an optimal tree species composition for forest plantations in buffer zones of nature reserves and in other areas where maintaining biodiversity is a major concern.
3668566|Data are presented on the results obtained from moist chamber cultures prepared with bark samples of three tree species from the United Kingdom and from Spain, which were watered with simulated acid rain. Both the number and variety of myxomycetes were found to be adversely affected by the constant acidification of the substrate, in spite of the buffering action demonstrated by the bark. The average number of species per culture also decreased with increasing acidity. Although some species appeared in acidified cultures at all the tested pH values, most species appeared only at three or fewer of those values. Of the myxomycetes that appeared across the pH range tested, fewer individuals within each species appeared at pH 3 and 4. This study lends further support to the idea that corticolous myxomycetes are susceptible to alterations in pH, and that the pH changes are buffered to some extent on the living tree, either by the microflora or by the bark.
3668567|In 1974-1975 moist chamber cultivations with bark of living trees were made in the Botanical Garden of the University of Helsinki, chosen to represent a polluted area in the centre of Helsinki. At present, in 2002, the air in the area has improved. The concentrations of sulphur dioxide and lead have clearly decreased and average concentrations of nitrogen oxides and carbon monoxide have diminished. 28 years ago the pH of the tree barks varied from 2 to 9. It was now more stable varying from 3 to 7. In 1974-1975 only six species of myxomycetes emerged on the barks of living trees. Now, 28 years later, 14 species were identified. During the same period the number of corticolous lichen species increased from two to 18.
3668571|Comparative light microscope (LM) and scanning electron microscope (SEM) observations were made from type specimens and field collections of Diachea subsessilis and D. deviata. The objective was to determine the taxonomic validity of D. deviata. Observations indicate that Diachea subsessilis and D. deviata are conspecific. Diachea deviata was described from an aberrant, prematurely dried collection. Developmental variation was seen in fruiting body size and shape, stalk length, peridium iridescence and texture, and branching patterns of the capillitial threads. Reticulate spore wall ornamentation was a constant character even under unfavorable environmental conditions. A composite species description of D. subsessilis is presented based mostly on SEM observations of specimens from various geographical regions.

3668559|A critical updating of myxomycete records from the Hawaiian Islands has resulted in 102 identified species. In addition, two or three specimens may represent undescribed taxa and are commented upon. Licea rufocuprea, previously known from Japan and the United States, is reported from Hawaii based upon a previously misidentified specimen. Several species that are common in tropical and warm-temperate regions are found in Hawaii. Since most myxomycete species are widespread it is difficult to discuss myxomycetes from a biogeographical point of view. Many species tend to occur wherever substratum and microclimate are suitable.
3668562|One surprising result from recent studies carried out in Neotropical moist forests is that myxomycete biodiversity seems to be greatest in microhabitats located above the ground, whereas in temperate and boreal forests it is greatest in microhabitats associated with the forest floor. Myxomycetes appear to be organisms adapted to highly fluctuating conditions of environmental moisture, but continuously high moisture levels apparently do not favor their growth and development. In addition to their apparent displacement from forest floor (relatively moist) to aerial (relatively drier) microhabitats, the majority of the myxomycetes encountered in Neotropical moist forests are characterized by a phaneroplasmodium, which is robust, can achieve considerable size in some species, and appears to tolerate the two extremes of the moisture gradient better than the other types of plasmodia found in myxomycetes. The objective of the present study, which is still ongoing, was to investigate the quantitative ecology and distributional relationships of myxomycetes associated with aerial litter microhabitats in tropical forests of northern Queensland, Australia. More than 90% of the 69 moist chamber cultures prepared with samples of aerial litter collected from two study sites yielded some evidence (either plasmodia or fruiting bodies) of myxomycetes. Didymium squamulosum was the single most abundant species, with Physarum compressum and Physarum pusillum also important. All three of these are among the more characteristic myxomycetes associated with aerial litter in Neotropical forests, which suggests that the aerial litter microhabitat may support compositionally similar assemblages of species in the tropical moist forests of Australia.
3668560|During the period of 1995 to 2002, biotic surveys for mycetozoans (slime moulds) were carried out in a number of study areas in Central and South America to document more completely the species associated with tropical forests and other ecosystems in this region of the world. Primary emphasis of these surveys was on myxomycetes; more limited data were obtained for dictyostelids and protostelids, two other groups of mycetozoans that share some of the same microhabitats as myxomycetes. The body of data represented by the more than 8,000 field and moist chamber collections of myxomycetes accumulated during these surveys have provided evidence for a number of ecological patterns not previously reported for myxomycetes. The most important of these are that (1) both overall abundance and species richness of myxomycetes appear to be lower in tropical forests than in temperate forests, (2) species richness and [especially] relative abundance increase with decreasing moisture conditions, and (3) in tropical forests, distinct assemblages of myxomycetes are associated with microhabitats that have no counterparts in temperate forests. The most extensive of the latter is the aerial litter (dead but still attached plant parts) microhabitat, where myxomycetes appear to be especially abundant and diverse. Most of the dictyostelids recovered from samples collected in the various study areas are cosmopolitan forms or species known to have tropical or subtropical affinities. However, one new species (Acytostelium minutissimum), several other forms that possibly represent undescribed species, and a number of species not previously known from the Neotropics also were recorded. For the most part, the species of protostelids associated with Neotropical forests are the same as those found in temperate regions of the world, and species richness in this group appears to be highest in mesic but not wet habitats. Microhabitat trends of particular species of protostelids appear to vary with habitat. Overall in tropical montane habitats, protostelids are more abundant in aerial microhabitats than in ground microhabitats while in mesic habitats they are present in both types of microhabitats, but with some species displaying a preference for one or the other.
3668565|The Myxobiota diversity of the Garajonay National Park (Gomera, Canary Islands) is presented, with preliminary results of a chorological and ecological evaluation. Seventy-one species are registered, twenty of these are reported for the first time in the Canaries. A greater biodiversity is observed in the damp shady zones of the evergreen forest than in areas occupied by introduced vascular plant species or communities of xerophytic scrubs. With regard to the substrate, the ligno-corticolous group is the best represented. Among the myxomycetes of Garajonay National Park, the dominant chorological element is the Holarctic.
3668563|The number of occurrences and areas of fructification colonies of myxomycetes were investigated on decaying wood of deciduous broadleaf and coniferous wood in a natural temperate forest in the Nishikuma ravine (900-1200 m alt.) in Kochi prefecture, Southwest Japan. Forty-seven species of wood-inhabiting myxomycetes were found from 397 collected samples. In the progression of decay, the species of myxomycetes changed on both kinds of wood. The number of recorded species increased and reached their maximum on rather decayed wood and strongly decayed wood of both kinds of wood. They decreased on hard wood and brittle and spongy wood. The distribution pattern of eight species (Physarum viride, Lycogala epidendrum, Arcyria cinerea, Cribraria cancellata and others) on both kinds of wood had something in common. The common species on both kinds of wood were placed regularly according to the state of decay. On the strongly decayed and softer wood, the species distribution was obviously different in terms of species and colony sizes.

3668557|The activities of the first tree canopy biodiversity survey for cryptogams (myxomycetes, macrofungi, mosses, liverworts, and lichens) are reviewed. The All Taxa Biodiversity Inventory under the rubric of Discover Life in America represents a research effort to survey all life forms in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. The double rope climbing method is described and illustrated. The public understanding of biodiversity was emphasized through print, exhibitions, and the television media. Student research experiences in the GSMNP resulted in the discovery of a new species of Diachea and an unusual epiphytic habitat for the fern Polypodium appalachianum. Students also experienced night field trips to collect myxomycetes with a flashlight and observation and photography of slugs feeding on the immature sporangial stages of the myxomycete Stemonitis axifera. Preliminary results suggest that the myxomycetes are the only group of targeted tree canopy organisms that are restricted to the bark and epiphytes of living trees. Ninety-five myxomycete species were harvested, mostly from moist chamber cultures derived from bark samples taken from the tree canopy. Bark samples were taken from: Juniperus virginiana, Fraxinus americana, Quercus alba, Liriodendron tulipifera, Acer rubrum, and Pinus strobus. Over 500 moist chamber cultures resulted in 52 new myxomycete records from the tree canopy. Seven new records were collected from ground sites. The total myxomycete species now known from the Park is 212. Bark sample characteristics such as pH, tree height, and water holding capacity were analyzed for different tree species to determine their relationship to myxomycete species assemblages. Occurrence and abundance of certain myxomycete species are related to differences in bark pH. Fieldwork during the summer of 2000 resulted in 191 lichen taxa collected from the tree canopy with 83 taxa new to the Park. Tree canopy species of lichens, macrofungi, mosses, and liverworts were also known from ground sites.
3668570|A survey of the biosystematic studies in the myxomycetes indicates that the currently recognized morphospecies are generally species complexes consisting of a number of genetically isolated regional allopatric and/or sympatric biological species and numerous small (rarely large) apomicitic clones. Other variations include a single biological species with or without apomictic clones, or apomictic clones without a biological species. Stalk and sporangial color, columella shape, and sporangial cluster morphotypes, which are produced by variations at a few genes, also occur within a genetic group. Biotypes that have small plasmodia, rapid life cycles, and dwarf or reduced numbers of sporangia can be isolated from ephemeral or low nutrient habitats and are also part of a larger genetic group. This information indicates that many of the recently described species are probably based on restricted clonal lines, which should not be recognized at the species level. Also, some commonly accepted morphospecies are only morphological variants, which can be found within a single biological species. Thus, the description of new species should be based upon an extensive collection of specimens so that these variations and small clonal populations can be excluded.
3668491|The wide variety of forms in myxomycetes, with regard to fructifications as well as the plasmodium, offers a fascinating field for the study of pattern formation. The manner of disposition of the fructifations over the substratum seems to be fairly constant for a given taxon. The evolution from the sessile form to the stipitate, and the subsequent elongation of the stipe has necessitated a strengthening of the stipe and balancing of sporangial weight. These have been achieved in different ways in the different taxa. And then, the spore ornamentation is so diverse that mycological terms seem inadequate to describe them, and the adoption of palynological terms has been suggested. The chemical nature of the different parts of the fructification and of the pigments, is as yet only partially understood. Despite widespread investigations, the metamorphosis of the living, pulsating plasmodium into the exquisitely sculptured, hibernating fructifications remains enigmatic. Morphogenesis in fungi is said to occur within a network of factors which include metabolic processes, macromolecular structures, the mechanical, chemical and electrical field within the organism, and the extracellular matrix; and this would also be true for myxomycetes. For a better understanding of these interactions, we must appeal for a closer collaboration of general myxomycologists with physicists, chemists and molecular biologists.
3668500|The taxonomy of the New World species of Azolla has been the subject of much debate and remains unsatisfactory. Since 1944 most authors, mainly Americans, recognize four species: A. caroliniana, A. filiculoides, A. mexicana and A. microphylla. The present study is based on a comprehensive review of the literature and on original observations, by optical and scanning electron microscopy, of numerous samples cultivated in our laboratory as well as herbarium exsiccata. Observation of the type specimens confirms the opinion of some authors that A. caroliniana and A. microphylla are synonyms of the previously described A. filiculoides. The ferns named A. caroliniana and A. microphylla by most authors, including the American taxonomists in their recent works, are different from their type specimens. The study also shows that the Mettenius conception, proposed as early as 1867, has to be rehabilitated: two species only exist in America. According to the priority rule they must be named A. cristata and A. filiculoides.
3668492|Through several separate studies made in our laboratory we have found that in routine cultures myxomycete plasmodia are invariably associated -- closely and tenaciously -- with one bacterial species, and thus monoxenic. The association is not species-specific, but the bacteria in most cases belong to the Enterobacteriaceae. The bacteria can be easily isolated and grown in pure culture, but this is not always true for the plasmodium. From parallel studies conducted with monoxenic plasmodial structures and pure cultures of the bacterial associate, we find that the monoxenic plasmodia can fix atmospheric nitrogen, produce extracellular enzymes and degrade certain types of wood and litter, and also tolerate high concentrations of various chemical pollutants, while the bacterial associates in pure culture exhibit none of these properties. Thus the association confers on the organism certain properties not manifest in the individual partners. As a result of some of our natural observations we presume this to occur in nature, and ascribe to the myxomycetes a positive role in the recycling of nutrients on the forest floor.
3668497|Arthur Lister (1830-1908) and his daughter, Gulielma (1860-1949), are closely associated with the myxomycete collections at the Natural History Museum (BM), which they used for the three editions of the Monograph of Mycetozoa. There are additional sketchbooks and the working illustrations for a fourth edition of their work.
3668499|As one component of the All Taxa Biodiversity Inventory (ATBI) being carried out in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, an ongoing survey of dictyostelid cellular slime molds has yielded a combination of previously reported species together with additional Park records as well as a number of species possibly new to science. As results from previous studies conducted elsewhere in the world have indicated, there appear to be assemblages consisting of particular species of dictyostelids characteristically associated with certain habitats. This certainly seems to be true in the Park. In many cases, the distribution pattern of a given species can be related to the differences that exist from place to place for such environmental parameters as elevation, soil pH and the overall moisture regime. In this paper, we report on the current status of the ATBI dictyostelid survey and discuss some of the more interesting and/or unusual species discovered thus far.

3668501|Diversity and distribution of plant species at 105 sites (63 in the Oases of the Western Desert and 42 in the Nile land) of seven major irrigated croplands in Egypt was surveyed using stratified sampling technique. These sites were distributed as follows: twelve in Siwa Oasis, fifteen in Bahariya Oasis, fifteen in Farafra Oasis, seven in Dakhla Oasis, fourteen in Kharga Oasis, fifteen in Faiyum Governorate and 27 in central Delta region. A total of 328 species belonging to 212 genera and 59 families were recorded. The families with the highest number of species (60% of the total) were Poaceae (53 species), Asteraceae (37 species), Fabaceae (29 species), Cyperaceae (ninteen species), Chenopodiaceae (fifteen species), Brassicaceae (thirteen species), Caryophyllaceae (twelve species), Euphorbiaceae and Polygonaceae (ten species each). Six alien weedy species were recorded for the first time. In this study, five main habitat types were recognised which are supported by spatial analysis: i, farmlands (including irrigated crop-fields and orchards); ii, canal banks; iii, reclaimed lands; iv, waste lands (including moist and abandoned saline field plots but not salt marshes) and; v, water bodies. TWINSPAN and DCA analyses of 105 sites & 186 species of frequency percentages >5% showed six site groups, with the Nile land and the Oases croplands as clearly separated agro-ecosystems.

3668493|Populations of cellular slime molds (CSM) isolated from fifteen separate collections by the first four authors were compared from Puerto Rico, St. John, Virgin Islands, and San Salvador, Bahamas. These islands differ in size as well as number of forest habitats. The island populations in turn were compared to those of an optimal mainland habitat at Tikal, Guatemala. Our main objective was to determine what effects habitat diversity, area and insular environment have on CSM diversity. Although other studies have investigated species-area relationships, most have focused on either animals or plants. Our purpose has been to determine how a specific group of microorganisms, the cellular slime molds, responds to island biogeography. In addition, we were also interested in finding endemic examples of speciation in the Caribbean. Two endemics were found: Polysphondylium luridum from Puerto Rico and St. John and P. equisetoides from San Salvador. The latter species is described as part of this paper.

3668575|Phytosociological, ecological and dendrometric surveys have been done in the forest plantations of Djigb and Lama in south-Benin. The factorial analysis of correspondence helps to identify two Chromolaena odorata communities: one on the "terre de barre" (ferralitic soil) and the other on the black cotton soils. At 5% of probability level, there is no significant difference between the specific diversity of the two Chromolaena odorata communities: the mean value of the species richness is 33 per relev on the "terre de barre" against 31 on the black cotton soils; the Shannon index value is 1.6 on the "terre de barre" against 2.2 on the black cotton soils; the evenness coefficient of Pielou is respectively 0.48 and 0.44 on "terre de barre" and the black cotton soils. From the specific combination of the Chromolaena odorata communities within the study area, we deduce that these communities can be used to identify general soil-types. However, due to the important variability of plantation productivity within these communities, they can not reliably be used to identify forest sites. /// Les plantations forestires  Chromolaena odorata dans les secteurs de Djigb et de la Lama au sud-Bnin ont fait l'objet d'investigations phytosociologique, cologique et dendromtrique. 3668577|Seasonal lakes are a characteristic landscape element of the semi-arid Sahel zone in West Africa; their vegetation has a significant economic importance and is intensively used; water levels are subjected to large fluctuations. Based upon the example of Burkina Faso, the ephemeral, herbaceous vegetation of standing, seasonal freshwater lakes was studied. Field survey with phytosociological relevs took place at eleven lakes. The vegetation is classified into floristically and ecologically well defined units: several associations and rank-free communities are documented, most of them can be found with subassociations or in fragmentary and floristically impoverished forms. Duration of flooding, height of inundation, and utilisation intensity are the most important differentiating factors. The plant communities are integrated into the existing syntaxonomical scheme of West African wetland vegetation. They can be grouped into two phytosociological alliances: Sagittario guayanensis-Nymphaeion maculatae (vegetation of nutrient rich shorelines with muddy substrate) and Brachiario muticae-Cynodontion dactyli (dense swards at sandy, wet places with an eutrophication through animals). The plant communities are presented in a constancy table. Their distribution, ecological and floristic relationships are described and discussed in a larger geographical context.

10.2307/3668750|This study represents a first attempt to reconstruct the phylogenetic relationships in the genus Dictyota by means of an RFLP analysis of the amplified Internal Transcribed Spacer 1 of the ribosomal region (ARDRA-ITS1). To overcome DNA extraction problems, a new protocol based on a combination of a CTAB method and a Sephaglass Bandprep Kit is presented. Seven species, mostly including more than one specimen, were included. Padina boergesenii was used as an outgroup. The inferred phylogenetic picture was congruent with the morphological-anatomical data. Specimens belonging to the same species invariably group together and differences among geographically isolated populations are reflected in the tree. Parsimony-based bootstrap and jackknife supports for basal nodes are generally very low and phylogenetic relationships between species are poorly resolved. This poor resolution can probably be attributed to the considerable variation in length of the ITS1 region among the species. This variation causes difficulties in sequence alignments and calls into question the use of this marker as a general tool in the genus.
10.2307/3668751|A cladistic analysis of 5S nuclear ribosomal DNA non-transcribed spacer (5S-NTS) sequences representing 55 Saintpaulia accessions and one Streptocarpus outgroup taxon is presented. All formally described and potential Saintpaulia taxa are included except for S. 'mafiensis' and the possibly extinct S. inconspicua. Most notably, Saintpaulia shumensis, the highest elevation species in the Usambara Mountains, is resolved, albeit with marginal parsimony jackknife support, as the sister taxon to all remaining members of the Usambaras/lowland clade, which is otherwise poorly structured. It is hypothesized that Saintpaulia shumensis may show a relictual distribution in the Usambaras, as there appears to be a phylogenetic trend from higher to lower elevation among the major clades of Saintpaulia. Further issues discussed include the implications of intra-individual nucleotide polymorphism and the narrow genetic basis for drastic differences in trichome morphology, a cardinal characteristic for Saintpaulia taxonomy.

10.2307/3668754|Relationships among 40 species of the tribe Psychotrieae were estimated by cladistic analysis of nucleotide sequence variation in the rps16 intron (cpDNA). One strongly supported clade was found to include the genera Chazaliella, Chytropsia, Margaritopsis and Readea, and a number of species presently referred to Psychotria. It is suggested that this group should be treated taxonomically as one genus, the correct name of which would be Margaritopsis. The names Chazaliella, Chytropsia and Readea thus become synonyms of Margaritopsis. Margaritopsis in this broad sense is diagnosed by non-caducous stipules which are often marcescent, becoming papyraceous when old, by a greenish (rather than reddish or brownish) drying colour, planoconvex pyrenes with horny endocarp and distinct, marginal germination slits, and seeds with pale testa without an ethanol-soluble pigment. With this circumscription, Margaritopsis has ca. 10 species in the neotropics, ca. 25 in Africa, ca. 12 in New Caledonia and Fiji, and a few in SE Asia. It is doubtful if it occurs in The Philippines, New Guinea, Australia, Samoa or Hawaii. Three new combinations are made, Margaritopsis membranacea (Gillespie) L.Andersson, M. astrellantha (Wernh.) L.Andersson, and M. abrupta (Hiern) L.Andersson.
10.2307/3668753|Systematic research on the genus Panicum in the main Belgian public herbaria and some smaller private herbaria revealed a considerable number of new and other interesting data. Sixteen taxa have been recognized in the course of the present study: P. bulbosum*, P. capillare (incl. the subspecies capillare and barbipulvinatum*), P. chloroticum*, P. clandestinum, P. coloratum*, P. cf. decompositum*, P. dichotomiflorum (incl. the varieties dichotomiflorum and geniculatum), P. hillmanii*, P. hirticaule*, P. laevinode, P. miliaceum (incl. the subspecies miliaceum and ruderale*), P. schinzii and P. virgatum*. Several taxa (marked with * above) -- in part ancient and exclusive records of wool aliens originating in the Vesdre valley -- remained unidentified so far and are thus first mentioned for the Belgian adventitious flora. At present the following taxa are becoming more or less naturalized: P. capillare subsp. capillare, P. dichotomiflorum s.l. and P. schinzii (partially as noxious weeds in maize fields). Regularly introduced with cereals (incl. oil-seeds or commercial seeds) are P. chloroticum, P. dichotomiflorum s.l. and P. miliaceum subsp. miliaceum. Much rarer but fairly recent casuals are P. capillare subsp. barbipulvinatum, P. clandestinum, P. hillmanii, P. hirticaule and P. miliaceum subsp. ruderale. Misinterpretation within the genus led to numerous wrong identifications. P. compressum, P. flexile and P. repens need to be omitted from the Belgian adventitious flora lists. P. dichotomiflorum s.l. and P. schinzii have widely been confused; the majority of the P. dichotomiflorum collections actually belonged with P. schinzii. P. hillmanii and P. chloroticum are closely related and much confused with P. capillare and P. dichotomiflorum s.l. respectively. P. texanum is regarded as a member of the genus Urochloa, following recent nomenclatural insights. The present paper provides a dichotomous identification key for the genus Panicum in Belgium as well as additional chorological, taxonomic and nomenclatural remarks.

10.2307/3668668|The flora and distribution of epiphytes was surveyed on quickset hedges in the Bafou village (1400-2800m above sea level) situated at the Mount Bambouto area (west Cameroon) using Johansson's methodology (1974). The study area was divided into three areas (northern, central and southern part) according to the altitude. The factor analysis shows that the central and the southern regions of the study site were similar as far as the floristic composition is concerned. Because of this fact, two major regions were recognized within the study area: region I (central and southern parts) and region II (northern part). All together, 68 species were recorded on 746 individuals of 12 host tree species (phorophytes). Among the 68 species, 58 species are present in region I while 31 species are in region II. In region I, 46.6% of the species are Monocotyledons, Dicotyledons are represented by 29.3% of the species and Pteridophytes by 24.1%. The largest family among the 16 families present in this region I is the Orchidaceae which is represented by 46.6% of the species. In region II, Dicotyledons are the most abundant group and are represented by 48.4% of the species. Monocotyledons and Pteridophytes are in the same proportion and each of those groups is represented by 25.8% of the species. Among the 14 families present in this region, the Orchidaceae is the most abundant group with 25.8% of the species. In region I, two phorophytes, Cola anomala and Dracaena arborea, are the richest in species and carry 35 and 34 species of epiphytes, respectively. In region II, Dracaena arborea, Spathodea campanulata and Cola anomala with 21, 17 et 16 epiphytes respectively are the richest in species. Otherwise Croton macrostachyus and Ficus chlamydocarpa are the poorest in the two regions. A detailed analysis of the distribution of epiphytes on Cola anomala in the northern, central and southern parts of the study site with the number of epiphytes as the dependent variable and the circumference of the phorophyte as a co-factor shows a significant difference between the three parts of the study site (F = 5,56; d.f. = 2; P < 0,0054). Furthermore, the number of epiphytes and the circumference of the phorophyte appeared correlated in the different parts of the study site (<latex>$P<10^{-6}$</latex>). The examination of the stratification of the epiphytes on Cola anomala tree shows that the species richness is different within the five strates recognized here. /// La distribution des piphytes vasculaires a t tudie sur les haies vives du village Bafou (1400-2800 m d'altitude) situ dans la rgion des monts Bambouto (Ouest Cameroun). L'analyse factorielle des correspondances nous a permis de constater que le Centre et le Sud sont floristiquement semblables. Une analyse plus pousse de la distribution des piphytes sur Cola anomala dans le Nord, le Centre et le Sud de la zone d'tude avec le nombre d'piphytes comme variable dpendante et comme co-facteur la circonfrence du phorophyte montre une diffrence entre ces trois parties du site (F = 5,56; d.d.l. = 2; P < 0,0054). 10.2307/3668706|This paper presents a preliminary inventory of edible macromycetes found in six Sudano-Guinean vegetation types from the protected forest areas of Wari-Maro in Benin (West Africa). Thirty edible species were found in 18 fixed plots (three per vegetation type). Edibility data were obtained from local populations and the literature. Mushroom productions were assessed per species and per plot using the number of produced carpophores and fresh weight (kg/ha). Edible macromycetes from the studied areas are for 86.6% ectomycorrhizal taxa belonging to Lactarius, Russula and Amanita. The total macromycetous fresh weight production of one season varies from 0.2 to 225.0 kg/ha, depending on the forest type. Open forests, i.e. savanna and woodland savanna, dominated by Caesalpiniaceae yield qualitatively and quantitatively more edible taxa than the denser and rivulet associated or riverain forest types lacking Caesalpinioid trees. Lactarius gymnocarpoides, forming ectomycorrhiza with Isoberlinia doka, is the most common and abundant species in the savannas and woodland savannas. Specific productions of the edible taxa are affected by host tree composition reflected in the forest type. Most species produce quantitatively more fresh weight in the first two months of the rainy season (June-July). Species showing a continuous production throughout the rainy season are rare. The study illustrates that the edible macromycetes from Wari-Maro forest have substantial importance as a renewable non timber forest product (NTFP). The limitations and the main factors, necessary for a succesful valorisation of these NTFP, are discussed. /// Cette tude donne l'inventaire des macromyctes comestibles, trouvs dans six types de formations forestires de la fort classe de Wari-Maro (Bnin, Afrique de l'Ouest) en rgion Soudano-guinenne. Un total de 30 espces comestibles a t obtenu dans 18 placeaux (trois par formation), les donnes de comestibilit ont t obtenues de la population locale et de la littrature. Le nombre de carpophores et la biomasse frache ont t quantifis par espce et par formation. Les macromyctes comestibles sont  86,6% des espces ectomycorhiziennes appartenant principalement aux genres Amanita, Lactarius et Russula. En une saison la production totale, toutes espces confondues, varie de 0,2  225 kg MF/ha suivant la formation forestire. Les formations ouvertes (savane arbustive, savane arbore et les diffrents facis de la fort claire  Isoberlinia doka) domines par les Caesalpiniaceae fournissent le plus d'espces comestibles, tant en richesse spcifique qu'en biomasse frache. Par contre, les formations denses fermes (fort dense de plateau et fort riveraine) pauvres en Caesalpiniaceae enregistrent les plus faibles productions. Lactarius gymnocarpoides, espce symbiote d'Isoberlinia doka, est la plus abondante de la mycoflore des formations  caractre de fort claire. Les productions spcifiques varient d'une formation  une autre. Quelques cas spcifiques sont traits. Les productions des espces sont le plus souvent concentres en dbut de la saison des pluies (juin-juillet). Les espces  production plus tale sont peu frquentes. L'tude dmontre que les potentialits des macromyctes de la fort classe de Wari-Maro, en tant que ressource forestire comestible ou produit forestier non-ligneux (PFNL), sont normes. Les facteurs importants pour le succs de la valorisation des ressources mycologiques dans la rgion sont abords.

10.2307/3668725|Woodland occurs in the Sudanian region of northern Benin where the tree stratum is dominated by Isoberlinia tomentosa or Monotes kerstingii at about 10 N. The objective of this study is to characterize floristic composition of herbaceous strata of woodland on the view point of life forms and species geographical distribution. Data were collected in relev plots of <tex-math>$400\ m^{2}$</tex-math> that had permitted to distinguish three plant associations. Species richness varied from 48 to 67 in the herbaceous stratum compared to 17 or 18 tree species per <tex-math>$1000\ m^{2}$</tex-math> in tree layer. Therophyte species were the most abundant (34 to 44%), but according to herbaceous strata structure defined by biovolume, hemicryptophyte species were the most abundant (77 to 94%). According to species distribution the base-element abundance varied from one association to another. The abundance of the base-element was low in disturbed stations due to the impact, when abundance of large spreading species was higher. Phanerophyte species abundance was higher among the base-element species than therophyte and geophyte species. While considering widely distributed species, therophyte species abundance was the highest (54 to 63%). This study shows that better of cattle grazing better understanding can be obtained of species richness and ecological patterns in Sudanian woodland using the abundance figures of respectively therophytic and phanerophytic species. /// La rgion soudanienne du Nord du Bnin est celle o l'on rencontre les forts claires qui sont pour la plupart domines au niveau de la strate arborescente par Isoberlinia tomentosa ou Monotes kerstingii  partir de 10 N. Cette tude dont l'objectif est de caractriser la composition floristique de la strate herbace des forts claires soudaniennes du point de vue structural et de leurs types biologique et phytogographique a t conduite dans trois associations diffrentes dans des placeaux de <tex-math>$400\ m^{2}$</tex-math> en moyenne. La richesse spcifique de la strate herbace varie entre 48 et 67 espces contre 17 ou 18 espces d'arbres sur <tex-math>$1000\ m^{2}$</tex-math> au niveau de la strate arborescente. Les throphytes sont les types biologiques les plus abondants (35  44%), alors que du point de vue structural ce sont plutt les hmicryptophytes cespiteux basiphylles qui contribuent le plus au biovolume de la strate herbace (77  94%). Du point de vue chorologique, l'abondance des espces de l'lment-base soudanien varie d'une association  l'autre. La valeur de l'lment-base est plus faible dans les stations perturbes par une forte intensit de passage des troupeaux bovins o l'on note aussi une contribution plus forte des espces  large distribution. Les phanrophytes sont plus reprsentatifs dans le cortge floristique de l'lment-base soudanien devant les throphytes et les gophytes. Dans le cortge des espces  large distribution ce sont plutt les throphytes qui sont les plus abondants et y contribuent entre 54 et 63%. On peut dduire de cette tude que les espces throphytes et phanrophytes traduisent par leur abondance, respectivement, la richesse spcifique et l'amplitude cologique des forts claires soudaniennes.
10.2307/3668666|In the Ivory Coast, the Sapotaceae comprise fifteen genera with the following distribution: African, eleven; pantropical, two (Chrysophyllum, Manilkara); paleotropical, one (Mimusops); afro-neotropical, one (Pouteria). At species rank, 43 Sapotaceae, all African, have been reported from different vegetation types in the country. They are trees or shrubs, but a single liana also occurs: Chrysophyllum welwitschii. Thirty-six of these species (83.7%) come from rain forest. The sudano-zambezian region counts five species, among them the very common "Karit" (Vitellaria paradoxa). Two shrubs are from the transition between rain forest and savanna: Mimusops andongensis and Pouteria alnifolia. Nine species are West African endemics. Three of them only occur in the Ivory Coast. Six Sapotaceae became rare or endangered due to the unfortunate degradation of the plant cover. 10.2307/3668721|This work is the first analysis of the totality of the plant biodiversity inventories made in the Odzala National Park. It deals especially with habitat diversity and phytogeographical groups based ou the correctly determined species of the curent flora. The global taxonomic list consists of 1141 species belonging to 125 families. Forest habitat is the most diversified with 806 species reaching 71% of the total, of wich 537 belong to the "fort de terre ferme". Grassy habitat includes 335 species reaching 29% of the total, 143 species belonging to the savanna. At the phytogeographical groups level, the basic Guineo-Congolian element is the most important with 666 species (58% of the flora). Species with very broad geographical area follow with 271 species (24% of the flora). Correlation between habitat and phytogeographical groups has been established. The predominance of the basic Guineo-Congolian element in forest sites where the human influence is lesser displays the stability of these habitats. The importance of species with very broad geographical area in grassy habitats illustrates the secondary or substitution character of these sites, mainly created by human activities. /// Ce travail constitue une premire analyse de la totalit de donnes cumules jusqu'ici, sur la biodiversit des plantes inventories dans le Parc National d'Odzala (PNO). Les habitats herbeux hbergent 335 espces soit 29% du total, dont 143 espces appartiennent aux savanes. Au niveau des groupes phytogograhiques, les espces de l'lment-base guino-congolais sont les plus importantes avec 666 espces (58% de la flore). Les espces  large distribution gographique suivent avec 271 espces (24% de la flore). Il a t tabli une corrlation entre l'habitat et le groupe phytogograhique. 10.2307/3668664|Numerous botanists have taken an interest in the flora of the copper-containing rocky outcrops of South Central Africa (Katanga, Zambia, Zimbabwe); some botanical collectors came by chance to these sites, while others, and among these the botanists Duvigneaud, Malaisse and Wild, have dedicated sites with copper-containing rocks a sustained interest. According to the number of collections made on these sites, some have been very well prospected, whilst others are still almost totally unknown from a botanical point of view. Moreover, the original vegetation of some sites is still intact, while mining activities in other sites have deeply influenced the vegetation, leading sometimes to total destruction and what appears to be extinction of five local endemic taxa. Maps showing the position of sites in South Central Africa are provided to demonstrate the degree of botanical exploration of the different outcrops; one set shows the total exploration, the other shows the activities of Duvigneaud, Malaisse and Wild. Based on these maps of exploration, and on maps of the degree of alteration of the sites, conclusions are drawn on the current knowledge of the sites and their flora, and on the need for future study of undercollected sites. /// De nombreux botanistes se sont intresss  la flore des gisements cuprifres d'Afrique centro-australe (Katanga, Zambie, Zimbabwe). Alors que certains se sont rendus fortuitement sur de tels sites, d'autres, (et parmi ceux-ci, particulirement les botanistes Duvigneaud, Malaisse et Wild) y ont consacr beaucoup d'intrt. Compte tenu du nombre de spcimens d'herbiers raliss sur gisements cuprifres, certains sites ont t particulirement bien herboriss tandis que d'autres restent pratiquement mconnus voire totalement inconnus d'un point de vue botanique. De plus, la vgtation originelle de certains sites est toujours intacte, tandis que, pour d'autres sites, l'activit minire a profondment modifi la vgtation, amenant parfois  une destruction totale de celle-ci, voire, dans un cas,  la disparition de cinq taxons endmiques locaux. Des reprsentations cartographiques montrant la localisation des sites sont avances pour reprsenter l'exploration botanique des diffrents gisements par l'ensemble des rcolteurs puis, respectivement, par Duvigneaud, Malaisse et Wild. La consultation des cartes d'exploration d'une part, ainsi que de celle ayant trait au degr d'altration des sites d'autre part, a permis d'mettre des conclusions relatives  la connaissance des diffrents gisements et de leur flore et de dgager la ncessit d'orienter des tudes futures vers les sites peu connus d'un point de vue botanique.
10.2307/3668663|The career of Paul Deuse started in Belgium in the "Hautes-Fagnes" during the post-war period, but came to its full expansion in Central Africa. Field worker, phytosociologist, trained as an ecologist and a palynologist, teacher, and endowed with a good experience of how to manage a field station and a museum, P. Deuse left Belgium in 1953 for a first three-month tour in Congo. From 1954 to 1956, he worked as temporary researcher for the "Institut pour la Recherche scientifique en Afrique centrale (I.R.S.A.C.)" in Mabali (Congo belge), where he prepared a doctoral thesis on the vegetation of the moorish "esobe" of the lake Tumba. After submitting his thesis at the "Universit de Lige" (1957), he was appointed senior research worker at the "I.R.S.A.C." and sent to Astrida (now Butare), in order to make a study of the peat bogs of the Ruanda-Urundi till 1959. After the independance of Congo, he returned to Astrida in July 1960, where he cut down on his research in pollen analysis to assume the responsability of Director of the I.R.S.A.C. Center till the independance of Rwanda. After that, the situation of the research center of Butare became still more difficult until the signature of the "convention belgo-rwandaise" end 1964, which founded the "Institut national pour la Recherche scientifique (I.N.R.S.)" of Rwanda, with P. Deuse as Director. P. Deuse was also part-time assistant lecturer (1961-1965) at the "Centre universitaire de Rumuri" (Bujumbura, Burundi), and senior lecturer (1963-1971) at the "Universit nationale du Rwanda" (U.N.R.). A part of the herbarium specimens gathered by P. Deuse before 1955 (406 nos.) are preserved in BR. In 1957 he started a herbarium in Astrida, with duplicates dispatched to Lwiro (LWO). The herbarium of Butare became the "Herbier national du Rwanda" (HNR) in 1965. After the death of P. Deuse, from 1977 onward, the I.N.R.S. was managed by the Government of Rwanda. In 1994, due to the genocide, the research center of Butare was sacked. /// Si la carrire de Paul Deuse a dbut en Belgique dans les Hautes-Fagnes  l'aprs-guerre, c'est en Afrique centrale qu'elle a connu son plus grand dveloppement. Homme de terrain, phytosociologue, cologiste et palynologue de formation, enseignant, nanti aussi d'une bonne exprience de gestion d'une station de terrain et d'un muse, il quitta la Belgique en 1953 pour un premier priple de trois mois au Congo. De 1954  1957, il fut chercheur temporaire au Centre de l'Institut pour la Recherche scientifique en Afrique centrale (I.R.S.A.C.) Suite  la dfense de sa thse  l'Universit de Lige (1957), il fut nomm chercheur senior  l'I.R.S.A.C. Aprs l'indpendance du Congo, il revint  Astrida en juillet 1960, o ses recherches en palynologie furent fort limites en raison de ses fonctions de directeur du Centre I.R.S.A.C. jusqu' l'indpendance du Rwanda. Ds ce moment, la situation du Centre de Butare devint de plus en plus difficile jusqu' la signature de la convention belgo-rwandaise, fin 1964, par laquelle fut fond l'Institut national pour la Recherche scientifique (I.N.R.S.) au Rwanda, dont P. Deuse devint directeur. P. Deuse fut aussi charg de cours  temps partiel (1961-1965) au Centre universitaire de Rumuri (Bujumbura, Burundi) et professeur ordinaire (1963-1971)  l'Universit nationale du Rwanda (U.N.R.). 10.2307/3668708|The identification of plants by indigenous people is based on recognising systems, which vary from one area to another. In order to understand the system used by the Malink, an ethnobotanical study was carried out in some villages of the Department of Sgula (in the north of Ivory Coast). After an inventory of the useful wild species in the area (scientific name, utilisation and ecology), vernacular names (in Dioula) were particularly investigated by the means of their local signification and etymology. This information was analysed and reveals various ways of identification and designation based on analogical or manner characters (morphology, gustatory, olfactory, onomatopeia, etc.). The Malink system takes into account botanical characters and ecological factors (habitat). These different recognising approaches are presented and discussed. /// La reconnaissance des plantes par les populations indignes est base sur des systmes taxonomiques qui peuvent varier d'un territoire  l'autre. 10.2307/3668696|Data on the amount of mucilage in mericarps of 400 species of Lamiaceae subfam. Nepetoideae has been obtained by tests and gathered from literature. The relative frequency of myxodiaspory (the condition of having mucilaginous diaspores) has been calculated for groups of species with similar biological characteristics, and the differences tested for statistical significance. The following results have been obtained: 1) Species that grow in dry habitats are more often myxodiasporic than species that grow in moist or damp habitats. However, myxodiaspory seems not to be more frequent in dry habitats in arid floristic regions than in dry habitats in more humid regions. 2) Species with small nutlets are more often myxodiasporic than species with large nutlets. However, most of the myxocarpic species with large nutlets are more strongly myxodiasporic than the myxodiasporic species with small nutlets. 3) Annuals are more often myxodiasporic than perennials. 4) Species with a reticulate or overall hairy nutlet surface are not myxodiasporic. 5) Tropical Africa has a particularly high relative frequency of myxodiaspory. These results suggest that the biological importance of myxodiaspory is primarily associated to the ability of the mucilaginous diaspores to adhere to animals or to the ground. However, the results do not support the prevailing view that atelechory is more important than epizoochory as a function of myxodiaspory. /// Des donnes sur la quantit de mucilage dans le pricarpe de 400 espces de Lamiaceae subfam. Nepetoideae ont t obtenues lors d'essais et rassembles  partir de la littrature. La frquence relative de myxodiasporie (prsence de diaspores mucilagineuses) a t calcule pour des groupes d'espces prsentant des caractristiques biologiques similaires et les diffrences ont t testes statistiquement. Les rsultats suivants ont t obtenus: 1) Les espces qui poussent dans des habitats secs sont plus souvent myxodiasporiques que celles rencontres dans des habitats humides. Nanmoins, la myxodiasporie ne semble pas tre plus frquente dans les habitats secs des rgions floristiques arides que dans les habitats secs des rgions plus humides. 2) Les espces  petits nucules sont plus souvent myxodiasporiques que les espces  grands nucules. Nanmoins, la plupart des espces myxocarpiques  grands nucules sont plus fortement myxodiasporiques que les espces myxodiasporiques  petits nucules. 3) Les annuelles sont plus souvent myxodiasporiques que les prennes. 4) Les espces prsentant une surface du nucule rticule ou totalement poilue ne sont pas myxodiasporiques. 5) La frquence relative de myxodiasporie est particulirement leve en Afrique tropicale. Ces rsultats suggrent que l'importance biologique de la myxodiasporie est principalement associe  la capacit qu'ont les diaspores mucilagineuses  adhrer aux animaux ou au sol. Cependant, les rsultats ne rejoignent pas l'opinion gnrale selon laquelle l'atlchorie est plus importante que l'pizoochorie du fait de la myxodiasporie. Traduit par le journal.
10.2307/3668703|Symbiotic methods for germinating Eulophia Lindl. and Polystachya Hook. seeds from terrestrial and epiphytic habitats respectively were established. Cultures, initiated from the seeds were grown on 2% oats medium and germination medium, alone, or oats medium supplemented with <tex-math>$10\ g.L^{-1}$</tex-math> banana fruit homogenate and <tex-math>$0.2\ g.L^{-1}$</tex-math> activated charcoal. The highest germination/differentiation, which took place after 7 days of inoculation, was obtained on the 2% oats medium with glucose (<tex-math>$2\ g.L-^{-1}$</tex-math>) and <tex-math>$NH_{4}NO_{3}4H_{2}O$</tex-math> (<tex-math>$1.0\ mM.L^{-1}$</tex-math>) as a source of inorganic nitrogen and supplemented with the additives. Development of protocorms in compatible orchid-fungus combination took place after the second subculture (30 days) from which seedling developed. Irrespective of the fact that the orchids showed possible specificity patterns at population level with their fungal partners in their natural habitats the in vitro symbiotic seed germination also showed significant tendency towards fungal specificity. This plant community is a type of Sudano-Guinean gallery forest with a relatively low absolute level of plant diversity, but an apparently high contribution to gamma biodiversity in Mali. Use of Gilletiodendron forest plants by the Maninka is low, although the endangered shrub Vepris heterophylla (Rutaceae) appears locally overharvested. Due to its economic value, Gilletiodendron glandulosum has the potential for overexploitation if human population growth continues or if the transportation infrastructure in western Mali improves to provide access to larger markets. No current conservation measures specifically benefit Gilletiodendron forest, although it is passively protected due to its occurrence in marginal areas within the Maninka land use system. /// La ncessit de mesures de conservation de Gilletiodendron glandulosum, une espce d'arbre endmique et vulnrable du sud-ouest du Mali a t value sur base de la valeur des forts  Gilletiodendron dans le cadre de la conservation de la biodiversit ainsi qu'en fonction de son utilisation actuelle et prvisible par le peuple indigne Maninka. 10.2307/3668704|Seed germination is consistently poor for the majority of Disa species, with in vitro culture revealing a decrease in species germinability as one moves from the winter to the summer-rainfall areas of South Africa. In an effort to enhance seed culture as a means of promoting conservation in Disa, the seed testa is highlighted as a regulatory factor in germination. A prominent feature of the mature seed is the variable colour of the testa in the ten species investigated, attributable to different levels of phenolic compounds. Total leachable phenolic content correlates positively with germinability and by inference, with species distribution. NaOCl treatment enhanced germination in certain species by scarifying the testa and enhancing permeability to water. Similarly liquid cultures and culture media containing activated charcoal decrease the time taken to, and result in elevated levels of, synchronous germination. Culture of immature seed (before phenolic deposition has occurred) also hastens germination. Scanning electron microscopy has highlighted basic differences between species regarding seed size and testa cell arrangement. All features of the testa and its influence on germinability in the summer-rainfall Disas are explained as adaptations to environmental conditions. The authors speculate on the occurrence of coat-imposed dormancy within Disa species endemic to the summer rainfall areas of South Africa. /// La germination des graines de la majorit des espces de Disa est uniformment faible et la culture in vitro rvle une diminution de la germinabilit des espces lorsqu'on se dplace des rgions d'Afrique du Sud o un hiver est enregistr vers celles o sont observes des prcipitations estivales. 10.2307/3668689|A number of examples exist of Gnidia species closely resembling each another, and possibly being synonymous. Many such species have been established on the basis of other non quantitative differences in character variation, but no studies have tested the validity of morphometric data in distinguishing taxa in this genus. In addition, no studies in this group have tested the patterns in and relationships between character variation. Morphometric analyses of features of involucral bracts, inflorescences and flowers of Gnidia species were performed to investigate patterns of diversity among these organs. In addition, bracts were assigned to classes representing different levels of modification from the leaves, and inflorescences were classified according to flower number and whether capitate or spicate. Species were also scored as having either static infructescences or elongating infructescences. Floral tube lengths, lengths of tubes from flower bases to constrictions above the ovary, sepal lengths and numbers of flowers in inflorescences were measured using species representing the diversity of these characters in the genus. Chi-square analysis, discriminant analysis, univariate nested analysis of variance and correlations were used to test character variation and relationship. Gnidia species are discriminated by their floral tube lengths, lengths of tubes from flower bases to constrictions above the ovary, sepal lengths and flower number. Involucral bract modification is influenced by inflorescence type, and species with elongating infructescences have unmodified bracts. These findings suggest that bracts protect flowers, especially the floral tubes surrounding ovaries. Bracts are most different from leaves in species that concentrate reproductive investment in the production of many-flowered inflorescences. Total floral tube length and length of tube from flower base to constriction are positively correlated as are total tube length and sepal length. Sepal length and flower number per inflorescence are negatively correlated and there is no relationship between total tube length and flower number among species. These results demonstrate how morphometric analyses contribute to testing the validity of taxa, especially within pairs or small groups of similar species, and subspecific taxa. /// Nombreux sont les exemples de ressemblance troite entre espces de Gnidia, certaines d'ailleurs tant probablement synonymes. Beaucoup de ces espces ont t tablies sur base de diffrences non quantitatives relatives  certains caractres mais aucune tude n'a test la validit des donnes morphomtriques qui ont permis la distinction de taxons au sein du genre. Par ailleurs, aucune tude mene dans ce groupe n'a envisag de modliser la variation des caractres et de leurs relations. Des analyses morphomtriques des types de bractes involucrales, des inflorescences et des fleurs de diffrentes espces de Gnidia ont t ralises de manire  tudier et  modliser la diversit de ces organes. Les bractes ont galement t classes en fonction de leur degr de modification par rapport aux feuilles et les inflorescences distingues d'aprs leur caractre capit ou spicul et le nombre de leurs fleurs. 10.2307/3668695|Long, narrow corolla tubes have evolved several times in genera of southern African Lamiaceae, such as Plectranthus, Thorncroftia, Orthosiphon, Hemizygia, Stachys and Salvia. A study of the pollination of Plectranthus in KwaZulu-Natal and the Eastern Cape of South Africa showed a nemestrinid fly, Stenobasipteron wiedemanni, to be the pollinator of the four species that have long corolla tubes. The proboscis length of this fly (19-30 mm) corresponds to the corolla tube lengths of the flowers (20-33 mm). This fly is restricted to forest patches and woodlands along the eastern parts of southern Africa, while long-proboscid species of the nemestrinid genus Prosoeca occur mostly in grassland habitats. It is postulated that S. wiedemanni is the pollinator of Stachys tubulosa, Salvia scabra, Salvia repens var. keiensis and Hemizygia ramosa in forest and woodland habitats. Long-proboscid species of the nemestrinid genus Prosoeca are suggested as pollinators of Orthosiphon tubiformis, Thorncroftia longiflora, T. succulenta, Hemizygia rugosifolia, H. gerrardii and Salvia repens var. keiensis, in grassland habitats. Novel distribution maps for four long-proboscid fly species are provided. This paper aims to discuss the distribution of long-tubed members of the Lamiaceae in relation to that of long-proboscid flies by relating the biogeography of the flies to that of the plant species. /// Des tubes corollins longs et troits se sont dvelopps dans plusieurs genres sud-africains de Lamiaceae, comme Plectranthus, Thorncroftia, Orthosiphon, Hemizygia, Stachys et Salvia. La prsence de cette mouche est limite aux lots forestiers et aux savanes arbores des rgions situes  l'est de l'Afrique australe, alors que les espces de nemestrides  long proboscis appartenant au genre Prosoeca se rencontrent principalement dans des milieux herbacs. Ca. thirty-five have collected during several years in a few floristic regions. Ca. thirty have collected during one year in many floristic regions. Ca. twenty-five have collected for 3-8 years in more than five floristic regions. Ca. fifteen have collected for more than eight years in more than eight floristic regions. 10.2307/3668690|The caesalpinioid legume genus Berlinia Sol. ex Hook. f. & Benth. as currently circumscribed, comprises about 18 species in two generic sections. A preliminary test of the monophyly of Berlinia and an investigation of its taxonomic position with respect to putative close relatives, Isoberlinia, Anthonotha, Gilbertiodendron, Pellegriniodendron and Librevillea was undertaken using analyses of molecular and macromorphological data. Nucleotide sequence data from two regions of the genome, a chloroplast region, the trnL intron, and a nuclear region, the internal transcribed spacer of the nuclear 28-18s ribosomal gene (ITS), were subjected to separate phylogenetic analyses. Both regions were assessed for phylogenetic utility in species level studies. A combined phylogenetic analysis of ITS data (including coded indels) and macromorphological data was undertaken. TrnL data provided only limited phylogenetic resolution. ITS data provided resolution at genus and species level offering weak support for a monophyletic Berlinia with Isoberlinia weakly supported as sister to Berlinia. Based on the phylogeny inferred from the analysis of ITS data, it was possible to speculate that Isoberlinia may be a recently radiated genus, the monotypic genus Pellegriniodendron may be conspecific with Gilbertiodendron and the genus Anthonotha may be paraphyletic. Macromorphology provided weak support for a monophyletic Berlinia but no support for the monophyly of the Berlinia-Isoberlinia clade. The combined analysis (ITS with macromorphology) provided moderate support, for the monophyly of Berlinia as currently circumscribed and weak support for Isoberlinia as sister group. Indels provided synapomorphies for several clades in the phylogeny inferred from the combined analysis. This paper is an extension of a study recently published (Mackinder 2000 publ. 2001), from which it differs by the inclusion of sequence (ITS) and morphological data for an additional four taxa. /// Le genre Berlinia Sol. ex Hook.f. & Benth. (lgumineuse caesalpiniode) tel qu'il est actuellement dlimit, comprend environ 18 espces rparties au sein de deux sections gnriques. 10.2307/3668736|Plant surveys were undertaken in 1995 in the 1922 and 1959 lava flows in order to assess species richness on these lava flows on Mount Cameroon. A total of 128 species were recorded out of which 21 (16%) were only found on lava flow and nowhere else in other ecosystems in Cameroon; they could be considered as a contribution of the lava flows to the maintenance of overall species diversity of the mountain area. Also, apart from the lava flow area it is difficult to find in one area such a high diversity of ferns, orchids and even woody species such as Ficus species and Hymenodictyon biafranum. The physiognomy of the recovering vegetation on lava flow is dominated at different stages of succession by different groups of plants, which also illustrates the successional pathway. The bare rock is first inhabited by lichens and mosses, followed by ferns, then herbs and climbers with stunted woody pioneers, and finally by immature woody pioneers. Comparison of observed data on species composition, basal area and density of plants on the 1922 lava flow and similar parameters in the intact nearby rainforest indicated that the turnover time on lava flow in the Mount Cameroon environment is at least 300 to 600 years. /// Afin d'valuer la richesse spcifique sur des coules de lave, un inventaire a t ralis en 1995 sur celles de 1922 et de 1959 au Mont Cameroun. On note aussi qu'en dehors des zones couvertes de lave, il est difficile de trouver en un mme endroit une telle diversit de fougres, d'orchides et mme d'espces ligneuses telles que les Ficus et Hymenodictyon biafranum. La physionomie de la vgtation reconstitue sur les laves est domine lors de diffrentes phases par des groupes floristiques illustrant la succession. All favoured a broader circumscription, which includes not only all members of Naucleeae sensu Ridsdale, but also Cephalanthus, Hallea, Mitragyna, and Uncaria, formerly placed in Naucleeae, Corynanthe and Pausinystalia.
