10.2307/3668731|Regeneration and succession processes in montane forests of Kenya and parts of Ethiopia were investigated. The slowly growing camphor tree, Ocotea usambarensis, regenerates mainly by suckers from old root systems. Undamaged seeds were very rarely seen, and, apparently are viable only for a few days. After natural breakdown of an old tree, the gap is filled by fast growing species, mainly Macaranga kilimandscharica and Neoboutonia macrocalyx, in the shade of which the young Ocotea suckers can establish. After the death of the secondary species, whose germination requires full sunlight and is inhibited in the shade, the Ocotea forest recovers. Large scale logging of Camphor trees predominantly destroys the regeneration of Ocotea and leads to secondary forest types, which regenerate in own cycles. The high number of big game was found to be without impact on the natural regeneration of Ocotea. The Cassipourea malosana dominated forest regenerates as a mosaic-climax without a single species becoming dominant. Cedar forests dominated by Juniperus procera regenerate most efficiently after fire. Without recurrent burning, the forests of the lower and middle part of the montane zone, regenerate to climax associations dominated by broad-leaved trees as Olea capensis ssp. hochstetteri, Olea europaea ssp. cuspidata and Podocarpus latifolius. On higher altitudes Juniperus procera always remains dominant even if fire does not occur for a longer time period. The high population density especially of buffaloes seems to inhibit successful regeneration in many parts of the Juniperion, due to intensive browsing and in particular trampling. The African Bamboo, Sinarundinaria alpina, shows a distinct growth cycle and can grow for extremely long periods in the vegetative state before flowering, especially so at the borders of its area. After flowering and dying of the bamboo, in most areas a dense Sambucus africana shrub is formed into which bamboo is invading from old rhizomes again. In Ethiopia, regeneration occurs directly, without an interspersed Sambucus stage. The uniform age of the Hagenia stands suggests that regeneration in these forests occurs suddenly after a disturbing event. Germination tests yielded, that Hagenia seeds are not germinating unless the competing undergrowth is removed. As fire is the only natural factor able to clear the grass layer of larger areas, it is assumed, that the reproduction of the subalpine forests depends on occasional burning. /// La rgnration et les modes de succession dans les forts d'altitude du Kenya et de parties de l'Ethiopie ont t tudis. L'exploitation  grande chelle des camphriers empche surtout la rgnration de Ocotea et conduit  la formation et au maintien de forts secondaires. Les forts de cdres, domines par Juniperus procera se rgnrent plus efficacement aprs le passage du feu. 10.2307/3668699|Molecular phylogenies have been generated to investigate relationships among species of Streptocarpus Lindl., the largest genus of Gesneriaceae in Africa. Of the around 146 species described, 77 have been included in a parsimony analysis using the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) of ribosomal DNA. The studies show that Streptocarpus is paraphyletic and at least three other genera are nested within the genus. Incongruence occurs in relation to the subgeneric division. Streptocarpus is currently divided into two subgenera, Streptocarpella and Streptocarpus, mainly on morphological grounds; the former including basically caulescent species with a functional shoot apical meristem, while the latter includes mainly unifoliates and rosulates with an abnormal shoot apical meristem. On the African continent the geographic distribution of caulescent species of subgenus Streptocarpella ranges across tropical Africa from Sierra Leone to the Indian Ocean, while species of subgenus Streptocarpus occur in central and eastern parts of Africa. The molecular data suggest a southwards migration and "progressive latitudinal speciation" of subgenus Streptocarpus in Africa. Some evidence suggests an origin of the genus on Madagascar but this is equivocal. The subgeneric split probably occurred before interchange between mainland Africa and Madagascar ceased, after the geological separation of Madagascar, and is consistent with the hypothesis of a land bridge connection between 45-26Mya. /// Des phylognies molculaires ont t gnres afin d'tudier les relations entre espces chez Streptocarpus Lindl., le plus grand genre de Gesneriaceae en Afrique. Parmi les 146 espces dcrites, 77 ont t utilises dans une analyse de parcimonie en diffrences morphologiques; le premier regroupe des espces caulescentes  mristme apical fonctionnel, alors que le deuxime inclut principalement des espces dont les individus, unifolis ou en rosette, prsentent un mristme apical anormal. Sur le continent africain, la distribution utilisant l'ITS du DNA ribosomique. Les tudes montrent que Streptocarpus est paraphyltique et qu'il regroupe au moins trois autres genres. La division subgnrique est problmatique. Streptocarpus est actuellement divis en deux sous-genres, Streptocarpella et Streptocarpus, principalement sur base de gographique des espces caulescentes du sous-genre Streptocarpella s'tend des rgions tropicales de la Sierra Leone  l'Ocan Indien, alors qu'on trouve les espces du sous-genre Streptocarpus en Afrique centrale et orientale. Les donnes molculaires suggrent une migration vers le sud et une "spciation latitudinale progressive" du sous-genre Streptocarpus en Afrique. L'origine malgache du genre est envisage mais reste quivoque. La diffrentiation des sous-genres a probablement eu lieu avant que l'change entre le continent africain et Madagascar ait pris fin suite  la sparation gologique de Madagascar. 10.2307/3668728|'Chipya' is the term applied to a wooded grassland vegetation type specific to northern Zambia. Based on experimental evidence from Zambia's Kasanka National Park, this paper attempts to answer some of these key questions raised in chipya ecology. Can chipya be clearly defined floristically and edaphically, and if so, how do these factors relate to mateshi-chipya-miombo dynamics? The results from Kasanka National Park suggest that chipya can be differentiated from miombo by the absence of the fire-sensitive genera Brachystegia, Julbernardia, Isoberlinia and Uapaca, and by its luxuriant herbaceous layer comprising the indicator species Pteridium aquilinum, Smilax anceps and Aframomum alboviolaceum. Finally, the evidence in Kasanka National Park suggests that chipya arises from a mateshi-chipya regression driven by fire. 10.2307/3668744|Using a GIS based approach, a new map of African vascular plant species richness is presented. The underlying phytodiversity dataset comprises metadata on the floras of 450 geographical units in Africa and Madagascar, including the data records used by Lebrun and Barthlott and collaborators for their maps. 151 of these were selected as suitable to analyse correlation of species richness with different environmental parameters in a GIS and to generate the map of African phytodiversity. For the production of the map we used a weighted overlay of the raw data, an interpolation approach and a multiple regression model. Best correlation with species richness were found for annual sum of NDVI, number of dry months and water balance. Centres of high species richness in Africa are the Capensis, Eastern Madagascar, the coastal areas of SE Nigeria, Cameroon, Equatorial Guinea and Gabon, as well as the Drakensberg mountains, and the East African Mountains. These areas are also centres of high geodiversity. For one aspect of geodiversity, the topodiversity, we present a first map for Africa. /// Une nouvelle carte de la richesse en plantes vasculaires africaines est prsente sur base de l'utilisation de SIG. L'ventail de donnes sous-jacent sur la diversit vgtale comprend des mtadonnes sur les flores de 450 units gographiques d'Afrique et de Madagascar, incluant les donnes utilises pour leurs cartes par Lebrun et Barthlott et coauteurs. 151 de celles-ci ont t considres comme valables pour analyser la corrlation de la richesse en espces avec diffrents paramtres environnementaux dans le SIG et pour produire la carte de la phytodiversit africaine. Pour la production de la carte, nous avons utilis une couverture pondre des donnes brutes, une approche d'interpolation et un schma de rgression multiple. The African and Madagascan collections were chosen as primary target group because of their importance for floristic work both inside and outside the "Laboratoire de Phanrogamie". 10.2307/3668737|The heathy, sclerophyllous vegetation type known locally in South Africa as 'fynbos' is not restricted to the Cape Floral Kingdom (CFK), but occurs throughout sub-Saharan Africa, Madagascar and the Mascarene Islands. The fynbos shrublands of these regions occur mostly in cool, montane environments where rainfall is high and soils are highly leached. Montane environments, however, are not the sole repositories of fynbos-type communities. Outcrops of Msikaba Formation (Pondoland) Sandstone in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, support similar shrublands, including many 'typical' fynbos genera and growth forms. The floristic and physiognomic resemblance of communities to the CFK, especially fragments of the high-altitude eastern (Afromontane) corridor extending into tropical East Africa, has prompted much speculation. A preliminary phytogeographical account is presented concerning the distribution of fynbos ('Cape') elements in the Drakensberg Alpine Region (DAR) and Pondoland Sandstone Region: two biotopes in southern Africa which share Cape elements. The significant sharing of Cape elements between biotopes suggests analogous growth environments. /// Le type de vgtation thermophile et sclrophylle localement connu en Afrique du Sud sous le nom de "fynbos" n'est pas restreint au Domaine floristique du Cap (CFK) mais existe  travers l'Afrique subsaharienne, Madagascar et les Mascareignes. 10.2307/3668729|Miombo woodland in Sengwa, dominated by Julbernardia globiflora, Brachystegia boehmii and Brachystegia spiciformis, exhibits clear small-scale patterning and variations in species composition. A hierarchical cluster analysis on species presence/absence data separated miombo woodland into eight sub-types, largely based on variations in the herbaceous and shrub species composition. Direct and indirect gradient analyses with variance partitioning showed that edaphic and disturbance factors accounted for 15.9% and 12.8% of the total variation in species composition, respectively, while their joint influence accounted for 3.1%. There was evidence that elephant-modified Brachystegia-dominated woodlands found on loose sands are being converted to Terminalia sericea-dominated woodland-thickets faster than the Julbernardia globiflora-dominated woodlands found on more compacted soils. It is concluded that fire and elephant herbivory have significantly influenced small-scale variations in species composition of miombo woodland in Sengwa while total exchangeable bases and silt significantly influenced natural floristic heterogeneity. /// La fort claire de type miombo  Sengwa, domine par Julbernardia globiflora, Brachystegia boehmii et Brachystegia spiciformis, montre clairement une diffrenciation  petite chelle et des variations dans sa composition spcifique. Des analyses de gradient directes et indirectes avec dcomposition de la variance ont montr que les facteurs daphiques et ceux lis aux perturbations intervenaient respectivement pour 15.9% et 12.8% dans la variation totale de la composition spcifique alors que leur influence conjointe tait de 3.1%. Il a t prouv que les forts claires modifies par l'action des lphants,  dominance de Brachystegia et sur sables meubles se sont converties plus rapidement en fourrs  Terminalia sericea que les forts claires domines par Julbernardia globiflora sur sols plus compacts. 10.2307/3668732|The Simen Mountains, a U.N. World Heritage Site in N Ethiopia (Gonder Administrative region), include extensive high plateau areas (roughly 3200 m to over 4000 m), steep escarpments and lower-lying parts (locally known as "Kolla" or "Simen lowlands"; below 3000 to below 2000 m) and are known for their high biodiversity. The "Simen lowlands", primarily harbouring afromontane vegetation, are richest in species, whereas the afroalpine belt -- although the most spectacular part of the mountains -- is the poorest. Erica forests of the escarpments and some of the plateaux areas are also rather species-poor. In general, species diversity decreases with increasing altitude. At present, approximately 550 taxa of angiosperms are recorded. The mountains, primarily known to biologists for their rare and endangered animals (including the endemic Walia Ibex, Capra walie), also harbour endemic plant species (at least 12; e.g. Rosularia semiensis: afroalpine, or Maytenus cortii: afromontane). In addition to these, more than 30 taxa occurring in the Simen are Ethiopian endemics (e.g. the spectacular afroalpine Lobelia rhynchopetalum, or the afromontane Polyscias farinosa). Interesting phytogeographical affinities to SW Arabia are noteworthy, e.g. Dianthus longiglumis or Chlorophytum tetraphyllum (only known from the Simen and Ethiopian mountains, respectively, and Yemen). Numerous taxa, both from the afromontane and -alpine zone, show a distribution stretching from the Simen southwards to the tropical E African mountains (e.g. Psychotria orophila, afromontane, or Trifolium cryptopodium, afroalpine), sometimes also with an extension to the W African mountains (e.g. Galium simense). Others (primarily taxa occurring in the afromontane zone of the Simen) show wide distribution ranges extending to S Africa (e.g. Halleria lucida, to the Drakensberg). Widely distributed Sudanian or Sudano-Zambezian species occurring in the "Simen lowlands" include Sterculia setigera and Stereospermum kunthianum, respectively. The Simen is a historic plant collecting locality, and -- according to our present state of knowledge -- type specimens of ca. 220 afromontane and -alpine taxa of flowering plants (out of ca. 550 recorded; i. e. 40%!) originate from the Mountains (primarily collections made by W.G. Schimper in the past century). In the past few decades, however, plant collecting was largely impossible (socio-political problems in the North of the country!), so that the botanical knowledge of the Simen was much poorer than for the rest of the country. Only in recent years, botanical exploration restarted. It is thus not surprising that during expeditions carried out between 1996 and 1999 nineteen taxa (mostly afromontane elements) were newly recorded for the Simen and Gonder floristic region. /// Les Montagnes du Simen, situes au Nord de l'Ethiopie (rgion administrative de Gonder) et classes Patrimoine Mondial par les Nations Unies comprennent de vastes hauts-plateaux (approximativement 3200 m  4000 m), des escarpements abrupts et des zones basses (connues localement sous le vocable "Kolla" ou "Simen lowlands"; coins de 3000 m  moins de 2000 m) et sont rputes pour leur biodiversit leve. Les "Simen lowlands", couvertes principalement par une vgtation afromontagnarde, ont la richesse spcifique la plus leve, alors que la ceinture afroalpine -- bien que la partie la plus spectaculaire des montagnes -- est la plus pauvre. Les forts  Erica des escarpements et certaines zones de plateaux sont aussi relativement pauvres en espces. En gnral, la diversit spcifique diminue lorsqu'augmente l'altitude. Actuellement, environ 550 taxons d'angiospermes ont t enregistrs. Les Montagnes, principalement connues des biologistes pour leurs animaux rares et menacs (notamment Capra walie, endmique), abritent galement des espces de plantes endmiques (au moins 12; par exemple Rosularia semiensis: afroalpine, ou Maytenus cortii: afromontagnarde). Par ailleurs, plus de 30 taxons des Simen sont endmiques d'Ethiopie (par exemple Lobelia rhynchopetalum, afroalpine spectaculaire, ou Polyscias farinosa, afromontagnarde). Des affinits phytogographiques intressantes avec le SO de l'Arabie sont remarquables, par exemple Dianthus longiglumis ou Chlorophytum tetraphyllum (exclusivement connues respectivement des montagnes du Simen et d'Ethiopie, ainsi que du Yemen). De nombreux taxon de la zone afromontagnarde et afroalpine, prsentent une distribution s'tendant du Simen en direction du sud jusqu'aux montagnes tropicales d'Afrique de l'Est (par exemple Psychotria orophila, afromontagnarde, ou Trifolium cryptopodium afroalpine), parfois aussi avec une extension vers les montagnes d'Afrique occidentale (par exemple Galium simense). 10.2307/3668739|In this study the possibility of rainforest outside the postulated refuge areas is explored by assessing the presence of rainforest Caesalpinioideae in Lop forest savannah mosaic in Gabon. In this dry area twenty-six tree species of this subfamily were located. Their physiological ability to cope with drought stress and their impossible migration from the nearest postulated refuge area strongly suggests that these species remained in the Lop area during the last ice age. Extrapolating this observation and incorporating all refuge indicator species outside the postulated refuge area, supports the idea that small fragments of forest persisted during the last ice age acting as microrefugia. /// L'existence possible de la fort ombrophile  l'extrieur des aires-refuges prsumes est envisage dans cette tude par l'examen de la prsence des Caesalpinioideae dans la mosaque fort-savane  Lop au Gabon. 10.2307/3668717|A phase of climatic disturbance and catastrophic destruction of Central African forests (in the region of south Cameroon, south Central African Republic, Gabon and Congo) occurred 2500 years BP (<sup>14</sup>C). This synchronous event for the different sites studied was manifested in either a brutal extension of the savannas, especially for the sites near the north (West Cameroon) and towards the south (Mayombe) of the Forest Domain, or a brutal extension of pioneer vegetation. Forest reinvasion began from 2000 years BP for some sites, or was a little later for others, according perhaps to the position of residual forests. This reinvasion still continues at the present time. Fires in the peripheral savannas can slow up this reinvasion, but in the long term the forests have continued to transgress into open regions. These major variations in the forest environment are illustrated by the history of two tree species of which numerous data have been able to be obtained: oil palm (Elaeis guineensis) and Okoum (Aucoumea klaineana). This massive disturbance which culminated about 2500 years BP is contextualised at the global and regional scale in the broader paleoclimatic framework of the upper Quaternary. Concerning climatic change and the dynamics of the monsoon on Central Africa, the key role which has always been played by Sea Surface Temperatures is shown. It is also shown that this vast disturbance which occurred alongside relatively "warm" regional and global conditions could be an "analog" to what could occur in Central Africa during the phase of "Global Warming" predicted for the 21st century. /// Une phase de perturbation climatique et de destruction catastrophique des forts d'Afrique centrale (secteurs Sud Cameroun, Sud Centrafrique, Gabon et Congo) est survenue vers 2500 ans BP (<sup>14</sup>C). Ce phnomne, synchrone pour les diffrents sites tudis, s'est traduit soit par une extension brutale des savanes, surtout pour les sites vers le nord (Ouest Cameroun) ou vers le sud (Mayombe) du Domaine Forestier, soit par une brutale extension des vgtations pionnires. 10.2307/3668735|Between 1990 and 2000 a number of vegetation surveys were undertaken on the Mount Cameroon area using mainly three methods: 0.25 ha sample plots, 20 m wide transects and rapid botanical surveys. A comparison of these methods in terms of data collected, operational characteristics and output relevance, revealed their strengths and weaknesses. The methods vary markedly in their ecological value (0.25 ha sample plots superior), taxonomic scope and rigour (rapid botanical survey superior) and logistic efficiency (transects superior). The combined outcome of all these surveys is discussed and recommendations made on the use of the rapid botanical survey in order to rapidly fill the remaining gaps on plant distribution. /// Durant la priode 1990-2000, une srie d'inventaires floristiques a t ralise au Mont Cameroun. Les points forts et les faiblesses des trois mthodes sont rvls par comparaison des types de donnes collectes, des caractristiques logistiques et des rsultats obtenus. Les mthodes varient nettement quant  leur valeur cologique (technique des placettes de 0,25 ha tant suprieure), leur rigueur et leur dimension taxonomique (technique d'inventaires botaniques rapides suprieure) et leur efficacit dans la ralisation des oprations (technique des transects suprieure). Les rsultats combins de tous ces inventaires sont discuts et des recommandations formules pour l'utilisation de la mthode d'inventaires botaniques rapides afin de combler rapidement les lacunes dans la connaissance de la distribution des plantes. 10.2307/3668715|AFlora is a database of ethnobotanical information collected in tropical Africa. Its purpose is to accumulate the information on plant use and nomenclature, and to facilitate effective information retrieval through Internet Web System. The information is specimen-based rather than taxon-based, and covers a whole range of man-plant relationships, direct and indirect, material as well as non-material uses. Graphic data (photographs) are also included in the database. In this paper, the structure of AFlora database, information included in each record, categorizations of uses and used parts are demonstrated, and some of the uses of the database for reference and comparative studies are discussed. /// AFlora est une base de donnes regroupant des informations ethnobotaniques collectes en Afrique tropicale. 10.2307/3668621|Records are given of 35 Lactarius species (Basidiomycota, Russulales) from drier Zambezian miombo woodlands in Zimbabwe. Most of them represent the first records for this country and all of them are the most southern records of the species on the African continent. Lactarius albocinctus Verbeken, L. brachystegiae Verbeken & Sharp, L. carmineus Verbeken & Walleyn and L. emergens Verbeken are proposed as new taxa. Fully illustrated descriptions are given for the first time for Lactarius aurantiifolius, L. nonpiscis, L. phlebonemus (with typification), L. pulchrispermus, L. roseolus, L. subamarus, L. urens and L. volemoides. Local uses and vernacular names of some species are documented.
10.2307/3668619|The floral ontogeny of Galopina tomentosa is investigated. Inflorescences consist of pleiothyrses whose smallest elements are three-flowered cymes. The upper flowers of each cyme are subtended by a bract with two prophylls, functioning as bract of the smaller flowers, and are surrounded by a variable number of colleters. Sepals fail to develop, are present as two pairs of different size, or as a single lateral pair. The four petals arise as broad diagonally inserted lobes around a central depression. The stamen primordia emerge on the inner slopes of the cup-like flower primordium in the interstices of the large petal lobes. The gynoecium develops externally as two shallow stylar primordia whereas most of the ovary is embedded in the receptacular tissue. The two erect styles are lined on their inner side with stigmatic papillae. Placentation is strictly spoken central-basal; an apical septum is formed after ovule initiation by downward growth of tissue subjacent to the styles and connects postgenitally with the placenta. Sterilisation of one of the sexes occurs at the onset of ovule initiation in staminate flowers, and after anther development in pistillate flowers. Differences of morphs become manifest just before anthesis with reflexed petals in staminate flowers and erect petals in the pistillate forms. There is no trace of a nectary. The use of the terms 'early' and 'late' sympetaly is discussed for the Rubiaceae. It is shown that the nature of a 'corolla tube' is not necessarily homologous in the family and relates to fluctuations of three processes: the extent of growth of a meristematic zone common to stamens and petals (stamen-corolla tube), the growth of a petal tube sensu stricto, and postgenital fusion of filaments with the corolla. The development of a concave floral primordium determines the existence of a peripheral collar or 'early sympetaly.' Gynoecial development is compared with other Rubiaceae. It is suggested that ovaries arise along a common pattern in the family. Differences in position of placentation are related with the heterogenous nature of the septum that consists of a basal and apical section. The flower of Galopina tomentosa is characteristic for the wind-pollinated Anthospermeae with a strong tendency for reduction. A comparison is made with other Anthospermeae and with Theligonum in particular.
10.2307/3668614|After having mentioned the few taxonomic problems still to be solved, the author reviews the 27 species mentioned by error in Jebel Uweinat, the planted and cultivated species, as well as the 8 species whose presence in Uweinat is extremely doubtful. The spectrum of the families shows that about half of the flora consists of Gramineae (23 species), of Leguminosae sensu lato (10) and of Zygophyllaceae (9). The spectrum of the genera (66) shows that they are represented only by a very small number of species (1-4). The spectrum of the species (table 4) shows that the flora of Jebel Uweinat, a massif of 1500-1750 km<sup>2</sup>, isolated in the Sahara in the heart of the vast Libyan Desert, in an area where rains are exceptional, is composed of only 87 species and infraspecific taxa. Such a small number reflects the very great poverty of the flora due to the extreme xeric conditions of the environment. From the comparison between these various spectra and those of Ennedi, the nearest massif to Jebel Uweinat (600 km South-West) but situated in the north of the Sahel where it rains for 2 months each year, it results that the flora of Jebel Uweinat is, for 2/3, similar to the flora of Ennedi but considerably impoverished by the excessive dryness, and, for 1/3, composed of eremitic species more specifically Saharan and well adapted to the xeric conditions. After having established the map of the botanical exploration of Jebel Uweinat (fig. 2), the author determines the degree of floristic exploration of the flora (fig. 3; 86 species found out of 87 after 52 days of prospection). In order to give a first outline of the composition of the vegetation, which is particularly scattered and very poor in species and individuals, the author classifies the species according to their total presence coefficient (PT) for the vegetation of the whole massif. In desert regions, this method gives indeed a better general view of the composition of the vegetation. This total presence coefficient is equal to the sum of the presences of each species in all the phytosociological relevs of the vegetation. The classification of species according to their total presence coefficient (table 11) shows that the 4 species most present in Jebel Uweinat are Fagonia indica var. indica (PT 132), Aerva javanica var. bovei (PT 127), Acacia tortilis sensu lato (PT 110) and Cleome chrysantha (PT 92). It appears in addition that 25 species were observed from 1 to 3 times only and this on a surface of 1500-1750 km<sup>2</sup> methodically prospected during 70 days. The author comes to the conclusion that various species, all perennial, seem in the process of disappearing, such as Cocculus pendulus, various Convolvulus, Cullen plicatum, Helianthemum lippii var. lippii, Salvadora persica var. persica and Tamarix arborea. From the analysis of the classification of the families according to the sum of the total presence coefficients of their species (table 13), it arises that the 4 families most present in Jebel Uweinat are now Leguminosae sensu lato, closely followed by Zygophyllaceae and, then, Gramineae and Capparaceae. The author gives then an outline of the vegetation of the whole massif of Jebel Uweinat, based on the total presence coefficients and in which are listed the families, genera and species most present in Jebel Uweinat (table 14). The author applies then the principle of the total presence of the species according to the nature of the outcropping rocks, the altitude, the grazing and the biological types. In consequence of the extreme poverty of the flora, the existence of distinct floras according to the nature of the outcropping rocks does not appear at first sight in the field. But the analysis of the flora, using the total presence coefficients of the species, showed the existence of two distinct phanerogamic floras, whether on sandstones or on granites. If many species (30) are present as well on sandstone as on granite, there are also many species (44) present on sandstone and not on granite and relatively many species (12) present on granite and not on sandstone. Several distribution maps of species illustrate the various types of presence met according to the nature of the outcropping rocks (fig. 5-10). After having determined the altitudinal amplitude of the species present on granite or sandstone, the author's conclusion is that there are no specific levels, neither on granite nor on sandstone. On the other hand, in spite of the extreme poverty of the flora, the author has been able to determine uppermost altitudinal limits for groups of species. Three uppermost altitudinal limits and 4 groups of species were determined on granite (fig. 11), 4 uppermost altitudinal limits and 5 groups of species on sandstone (fig. 12). The author determines then the specific richness in function of the altitude on granite and on sandstone (fig. 15-16). The influence of the wild herbivores upon vegetation is then studied: gazelles (Gazella dorcas) and moufflons (Ammotragus lervia). The distribution map of these herbivores and their excrements (fig. 17) shows that they are more present on sandstones, which are characterized by the presence of a greater number of vegetable species and by total presence coefficients much higher than on granites. The list of the grazed species (43) is then given (table 24) and the spectrum by families of the grazed species is established (table 25). These species are mainly Gramineae and Leguminosae sensu lato, two families which represent more than half the sum of the total presence coefficients of the grazed species. Gazelles (one hundred approximately) are mainly present in the lower parts of the sandstones. They graze 34 species whose sum of the total presence coefficients reaches 861. They have therefore sufficient food and the pressure they presently put upon lowland vegetation seems relatively low. A certain balance between the hundred gazelles and the lowland vegetation seems to be reached. Moufflons (around fifty) are almost exclusively present in the higher parts of the massif, whether on sandstone or on granite, where the flora is poorer. They have only about 20 species to graze whose sum of the total presence coefficients only reaches 456. Moufflons are obviously in lack of food and the pressure they put on the high altitude vegetation seems very strong and results in overgrazing which leads to various altitudinal species becoming a rarity. This high altitude vegetation seems to be particularly fragile and its balance with the moufflons seems to be broken. It is therefore to fear that some altitudinal species might disappear. The author then reviews the non-grazed species (43) and gives the reasons of this non-grazing. The above-mentioned statistical data show that the selective pressure of the wild herbivores upon vegetation results not only in the overgrazing and the progressive rarefaction of certain grazed species, but also in the survival, if not the development, of many non-grazed species whose total presence coefficients appear among the highest of the massif. In order to draw up the biological spectrum of the whole vegetation, the species have been classified according to the various traditional biological types, to which is added the category of the pluriseasonal species. According to Gillet (1968:64-65), this category includes species appearing as therophytes but with some individuals behaving like chamaephytes or hemicryptophytes during the following season. These species are therefore remarkably well adapted to desert conditions, since their reproduction is always assured whatever the duration of the interpluvial periods. The total unweighted biological spectrum of the whole vegetation (table 26), based on the number of species which contains each biological type, shows that the therophytes are the most significant group (29%), followed by the pluriseasonal species (25.5%), the chamaephytes (19.8%) and the phanerophytes (11.7%). This spectrum, in which therophytes and pluriseasonal species are more numerous (54.5%) than other biological types, is characteristic of mountainous areas of central Sahara. The comparison between this unweighted spectrum and that of Ennedi (table 27) shows that from Ennedi to Jebel Uweinat, the increase in dryness results in a reduction in the percentage of the therophytes and phanerophytes and in a very strong increase in the percentage of the pluriseasonal species, which are remarkably adapted to xeric conditions. Next, the total weighted biological spectrum is determined (table 28), based now on the sum of the total presence coefficients of the species for each biological type. This spectrum shows that the most significant biological types are the pluriseasonal species (39%), the chamaephytes (28.1%), the phanerophytes (16.4%) and the therophytes (9.8% only). This weighted spectrum reflects the reality much better since it corresponds accurately to the state of the vegetation during the interpluvial periods, when most of the therophytes are inconspicuous, whereas pluriseasonal and ligneous species still persist. This fourth part ends in a toponymic map with the names of the main places of the Jebel (fig. 18). /// Aprs avoir mentionn les quelques problmes taxonomiques encore  rsoudre, l'auteur passe en revue les 27 espces signales par erreur au Jebel Uweinat, les espces plantes et cultives, ainsi que les 8 espces dont la prsence  Uweinat est fort douteuse. Ce spectre, au sein duquel les throphytes et les plurisaisonnires sont plus nombreux (54,5%) que les autres types biologiques, est caractristique des rgions montagneuses du Sahara central. La comparaison de ce spectre brut avec celui de l'Ennedi (tableau 27) montre que de l'Ennedi au Jebel Uweinat, l'augmentation de la scheresse se traduit par une diminution du pourcentage des throphytes et des phanrophytes et par une trs forte augmentation du pourcentage des plurisaisonnires, espces remarquablement adaptes aux conditions dsertiques extrmes. Le spectre biologique total pondr est ensuite tabli (tableau 28), bas cette fois sur la somme des coefficients de prsence totale des espces de chaque type biologique. Ce spectre montre que les types biologiques les plus importants sont les plurisaisonnires (39%), les champhytes (28,1%), les phanrophytes (16,4%) et ensuite seulement les throphytes (9,8%). Ce spectre pondr traduit beaucoup mieux la ralit sur le terrain puisqu'il correspond fidlement  l'tat de la vgtation en priode interpluviale o la plupart des throphytes ne sont plus visibles, mais o persistent les plurisaisonnires et les espces ligneuses. 10.2307/3668617|Four new taxa of Orchidaceae are described from So Tom: Liparis rosseelii Stvart (two collections), Bulbophyllum luciphilum Stvart (based one collection), Polystachya albescens subsp. principensis Stvart (sect. 10.2307/3668620|Wood of the Australian monotypic genus Monococcus is characterised by short, narrow vessel elements, simple and non-bordered perforation plates, alternate vessel pitting, short fibres with vestigial pit borders, scanty axial parenchyma, and multiseriate rays mainly composed of upright/square ray cells. Styloids are most abundantly present in the secondary phloem. Moreover, secondary growth produced by successive cambia occurs in woody stem parts. These data are compared to other Phytolaccaceae s.l. and a close relationship between Monococcus, Rivina and Petiveria (Rivinoideae or Rivinaceae) is confirmed. However, data on a wider range of taxa are required to support a separation of Rivinaceae from Phytolaccaceae s.s. on the basis of stem anatomy. The presence or absence of successive cambia represents useful taxonomic information for evaluating phylogenetic relationships in Phytolaccaceae s.l. and Caryophyllales.
10.2307/3668618|A new Rothmannia species (Rubiaceae-Gardenieae-Gardeniinae) named Rothmannia ebamutensis found in Banyang Mbo (Cameroon) is described. This species is characterized by its fruit with ten small ribs and covered with small white lenticels. The pedicel of the flower is 50-60 mm long. The species is limited to the submontane rain forest at the south-western part of Cameroon.

10.2307/3668615|This fifth part consists in the comparative study of the distribution areas of the 86 species known in Jebel Uweinat, a huge isolated massif, 1900 m high, situated in the heart of eastern Sahara, within the Saharo-Sindian regional zone. The purpose of this study is to determine the part of the flora of Jebel Uweinat which belongs to the Saharo-Sindian phytochorion and to estimate the importance of the neighbouring phytochoria. The author first reproduces the maps of the main phytochoria of Africa and S-W Asia (fig. 1-2) and also the map of the subdivisions of the Saharo-Sindian regional zone (fig. 3). The species are then classified into Saharo-Sindian endemic species and into various types of linking species. There are 18 Saharo-Sindian endemic species, i.e. a fifth only (20.93%) of the flora of the massif. This low percentage confirms White's opinion according to whom this Saharo-Sindian phytochorion should be considered as a regional zone. Table 1 shows that 6 out of these 18 species are Saharan endemics, 6 are omni-Saharo-Sindian species and 3 Saharo-Arabian species. There are no species endemic to Jebel Uweinat, contrary to various higher Saharan mountains where some endemism exists. The 18 biregional linking species (20.93% of the flora) are mentioned in table 6. It shows that the biregional links between the Saharo-Sindian regional zone take place nearly exclusively with the Somalia-Masai regional centre of endemism (9 species; table 9) and with the Sahel regional transition zone (5 species; table 8), i.e. with tropical phytochoria situated south of the Saharo-Sindian regional zone. There is no biregional link with the Mediterranean regional centre of endemism, nor with the Indian continent, contrary to various higher Saharan mountains where a residual Mediterranean flora exists in altitude. Table 12, including the distribution of the 18 triregional linking species (20.93% of the flora), shows that 14 out of these 18 links take place with the Sahel regional transition zone and the Somalia-Masai regional centre of endemism (table 13), therefore confirming the close relations between the flora of Jebel Uweinat and these two tropical phytochoria. The Mediterranean regional centre of endemism is not included among these various triregional links, which confirms the absence of Mediterranean influence. The 22 linking species between more than three phytochoria of the Old World (25.58% of the flora; table 18) are distributed amongst 14 palaeotropical species (table 19) and 8 species, most of them scarcely present in Uweinat, distributed in palaeotropical and in warm temperate regions situated north of the Saharo-Sindian regional zone (table 20). Finally, a group of 10 species (11.62% of the flora; table 21) consists of 6 pantropical species (table 22) and 4 subcosmopolitan ones (table 23). Most of these species are very rare in Uweinat and their introduction seems rather recent. The quasi-absence in Uweinat of subcosmopolitan weeds is worth mentioning. The author then undertakes the comparative study of the chorotypes of all species known in Uweinat and establishes the total unweighted chorological spectrum of the whole vegetation (table 24). The number of species of Jebel Uweinat present in phytochoria other than the Saharo-Sindian regional zone is specified (table 25 and fig. 4). It appears clearly that the species of Uweinat exist much more frequently in tropical phytochoria situated south of the Saharo-Sindian regional zone than in phytochoria situated north and east of this zone, like the Mediterranean, Irano-Turanian and Indian phytochoria. Among the various phytochoria situated south of this regional zone, it is in the Somalia-Masai and Sahelian phytochoria that the Uweinat species are more frequently present. It is clearly with these two phytochoria that the flora of Uweinat has the closest links. The total weighted chorological spectrum is then established taking into account the total presence coefficients (PT) of the species. This weighted spectrum (table 26) is more in accordance with the reality in the field since it takes into account the importance of the presence of the species. The links between Uweinat species and other phytochoria are then established taking now into account the importance of their presence in the field, i.e. taking into account the sums of the total presence coefficients of the species (table 27 and fig. 5). The resulting data indicate even more clearly the dominant importance of the existing connections between the flora of Jebel Uweinat, the flora of the Somalia-Masai regional centre of endemism and those of the Sahel regional transition zone, i.e. with the flora of two tropical phytochoria. The author then reviews the 7 Uweinat species with a discontinuous area (table 29). For 5 of them, the present area seems to be the remnant of a very old, dry and continuous tropical and subtropical area stretching from Sahara to South Africa through East Africa. From the comparative study of the areas of the species, it results that some areal limits appear within the Sahara (Saharan regional subzone, SS1, fig. 3) and within the Somalia-Masai regional centre of endemism. Within the Saharan regional subzone, three types of distribution have been noticed. Most of the Uweinat species are widely distributed within this regional subzone and are common through all the Sahara (table 30; fig. 6-7). A second group composed of 12 species (14% of the flora; table 31) is distributed in Sahara only south of a subhorizontal median areal limit situated a little north of the Tropic of Cancer (fig. 8-10). These species are distributed in dry tropical African regions and this subhorizontal areal limit through Sahara coincides with the northern limit of their area. This subhorizontal areal limit corresponds fairly well with the phytogeographical limit drawn by various phytogeographers between the Holarctic floral Empire and the Palaeotropical floral Empire. Finally, a third group includes species which, in Sahara, are distributed only east of areal limits situated in the eastern and western parts of Libya. These areal limits coincide with those of the vast Libyan desert (fig. 8). Five species (table 32), three of them being very common in Uweinat (Cleome chrysantha, C. droserifolia and Crotalaria thebaica), are only known east of an areal limit situated east of this desert (fig. 11). This desert seems therefore to constitute a barrier preventing the extension of some species further to the west. Finally, 6 other species (table 33), among which 3 eremitic species of Fagonia very wide-spread in Uweinat, are only known east of an areal limit situated west of this desert (fig. 12). This time, the same desert seems to constitute a barrier preventing the extension further to the east of some species only known west of it. Various phytogeographers have drawn one phytogeographical limit, either east (Eig 1931), or west (Drude 1897, Chevalier 1932) of this Libyan desert. Their phytogeographical limits coincide fairly well with our own areal limits. Our conclusions, contrary to these authors, seem to indicate the presence of two areal limits, one east, another west of this desert, as already suggested by Monod in 1957. The comparative study of the areas of species present in both Uweinat and the Somalia-Masai regional centre of endemism not only confirms the existence of an areal limit within this centre of endemism (fig. 13), but also shows that 2/3 of these species are known only north of this areal limit (table 34; fig. 14). It is therefore with the flora of the northern half of this centre of endemism that these species show most affinities. This areal limit, here also, coincides with a phytogeographical limit established by some phytogeographers. Considering the importance of this areal limit, it is worth asking whether a subdivision should not be recommended within this regional centre of endemism. In conclusion, according to this comparative chorological study, it appears that the present flora of Jebel Uweinat, except 1/5 of Saharo-Sindian species, is mainly a tropical African one, closely connected with the flora of the northern half of the Somalia-Masai regional centre of endemism and with the flora of the Sahel regional transition zone. This flora if nevertheless considerably impoverished by the increasing dryness of the climate and, in altitude, by overgrazing. Moreover the present work confirms the existence of the Saharo-Sindian regional zone (fig. 1-3) as well as the fact that the Saharan regional subzone stretches on either sides of the Tropic of Cancer (fig. 3 and 8). On the contrary, this work does not confirm the existence in Africa of a vast phytogeographical Region called Sudano-Zambezian Region or Sudano-Angolan Region, but it confirms the existence of White's Somalia-Masai regional centre of endemism which clearly extends beyond the Red Sea (fig. 13). As a conclusion, the interest of the comparative study of areas of species is emphasized in order to contribute to the subdivision of phytochoria in general and of the Saharan regional subzone in particular. 10.2307/3668651|Diatom studies of French running waters over more than twenty-five years revealed the recent appearance of a number of species which could not have been overlooked before because of their abundance or size. Their absence in modern European floras supports the idea of a recent introduction of these taxa in Europe. Their distribution and progression in France are examined according to available data. Taxa not yet found in France until 1990 but showing an important proliferation and rapid dispersal since that time are considered as invasives. This is the case, for example, for Gomphoneis minuta, a diatom originally described in North America, reported in Europe for the first time in the River Ardche in 1991 and presently occurring throughout southern France up to the Loire. Among the so-called exotic taxa, Navicula jakovljevicii, Achnanthes catenata, A. subhudsonis sensu lato and Nitzschia cf. tropica have probably been misidentified in the past. Their distribution must be reexamined from existing slides collections. A new species, Eolimna comperei, is described by light and electron microscopy; its recent discovery in France appears to be related to the introductions in Europe of a number of diatoms from other continents. The most remarkable taxa are of tropical origin and proliferate in summer. The abundance of Hydrosera triquetra in French estuaries and of Diadesmis confervacea in power plant discharges and various rivers in southwestern France, illustrates their recent acclimatization under temperate conditions. The study of the spatio-temporal extension of these as well as of less abundant forms of recent appearance, e.g. Capartogramma crucicula, Encyonema triangulum, Gomphoneis eriensis var. variabilis, Luticola mitigata, Luticola peguana, Nitzschia elegantula, Nitzschia dissipatoides or Gomphosphenia oahuensis, might provide indications of the warming of running waters in Western Europe due to the "greenhouse effect." /// Les investigations menes sur le rseau hydrographique franais depuis plus d'un quart de sicle ont permis de recenser dans les eaux courantes un certain nombre d'espces de diatomes qui n'auraient pas pu passer inaperues auparavant en raison de leur abondance ou de leur taille. Leur absence mme des flores europennes modernes semble conforter l'ide d'une apparition rcente. La localisation d'une quinzaine d'espces est dcrite ainsi que leur progression chaque fois que des donnes sont disponibles. Ont t considres comme "invasives", les espces non encore signales en France avant 1990 et qui ont donn lieu  de vritables prolifrations et dont l'extension est rapide dans les cours d'eau. C'est le cas en particulier de Gomphoneis minuta dcrit en Amrique du Nord, observ pour la premire fois en Europe dans l'Ardche en 1991, et qui colonise aujourd'hui toute la France mridionale jusqu' la Loire. Parmi les formes exotiques, Navicula jakovjlevicii, Achnanthes catenata, Achnanthes subhudsonis sensu lato ou Nitzschia cf. tropica ont probablement fait l'objet de confusions systmatiques par le pass et la confirmation de leur apparition rcente ncessite une consultation des collections existantes. Une nouvelle espce de Naviculaces, Eolimna comperei, est dcrite en microscopie photonique et lectronique. 10.2307/3668649|A total of 119 taxa, belonging to 23 different genera were recorded from 34 terrestrial moss samples in Northeast Greenland. The diatom flora is mainly composed of cosmopolitan taxa. The taxa with an arctic and/or alpine distribution constitute 32% of the total number of taxa observed, but constitute only 16% to the relative abundance. The mean number of diatom valves/g dried sample is 697.000487.000. Most important genera are Eunotia, Nitzschia and Pinnularia. Three assemblages are distinguished by a hierarchic-agglomerate cluster analysis and confirmed by a PCA-ordination. The Pinnularia obscura assemblage lives in the drier mosses. The distinction between the other two assemblages, the Fragilaria pinnata assemblage and the Eunotia fallax assemblage, is possibly due to differences in pH.
10.2307/3668653|The former distribution (1852-1943) in Flemish standing waters of diatoms included in the Red List for Germany and Central Europe is assessed through a survey of diatom assemblages from herbarium exsiccata of macrophytes and old samples. With few exceptions, a good historical representation of Red List taxa is observed in the Campine ecoregion only, as nutrient-poor non-alkaline waters are scarce elsewhere in Flanders due to edaphic conditions. The German list therefore does not appear to be optimal for general use in e.g. site evaluation, as it reflects the availability of a particular habitat much more strongly than habitat quality as such. Within the Campine region and where leached sandy topsoils are present, such applications are possible, however. This is illustrated by a comparison of historical and recent survey data showing that a considerable decline in Red List diatoms occurred here. This decline is especially apparent if relative abundance or abundance ranked data are considered, but less so at the level of species numbers. For regions with naturally more eutrophic waters, development of a specific list seems more appropriate. A more general case can be made to use only Red Lists compiled at the scale of ecologically more homogeneous regions (ecoregions) for applications that are sensitive to biogeographic bias. Whether the number of Red List diatoms, their percentage abundance, or both metrics should be considered in assessing biological impairment or conservation value depends on the water type in question. Accurate estimates of the number of taxa are, however, more difficult to obtain. The use of rank ratios may be considered to compare differently structured assemblages. Among the cryptobiota, diatoms appear to be an exceptionally accessible group for addressing historical changes in biodiversity.
10.2307/3668648|With the routine use of electron microscopy it has now become possible to obtain a detailed knowledge of the global distribution of silica-scaled chrysophytes. After the original opinion that they were restricted to cool temperate and subarctic environments has been abandoned, it is now clear that as a group they occur in all climates. Of the altogether 250 taxa, 19 taxa are definitely cosmopolitan, and further 34 taxa are widely distibuted. In addition, many more very small and insufficiently known species might belong in these groups. Others have specific distributions depending on suitable environment and on dispersal possibilities. The importance of investigation intensity and of available specialists for reaching correct conclusions is emphasized. Correct identifications are indeed necessary, but the species concept is inconsistent and purely morphological, and the use of molecular techniques in chrysophyte taxonomy and biogeography is only in its beginning.
10.2307/3668644|For more than a century Frustulia saxonica was considered to be an infraspecific variety of F. rhomboides. A search for the type of the basionym, Navicula rhomboides Ehrenberg, revealed that Navicula rhomboides is not a Frustulia. A lectotype is presented for N. rhomboides Ehrenberg. As a consequence twelve new nomenclatural transfers within the genus Frustulia have been proposed. From the original material of Frustulia saxonica Rabenhorst, type of the name of the genus, a lectotype is chosen from among the heteromorphic specimens which had been traditionally identified as F. rhomboides.
10.2307/3668643|Surirella brevicostata O. Mller is not a common taxon in tropical Africa. In this study, some morphometric studies could be effected on material from Lake Tanganyika, Lake Malawi (Nyassa) and Lake Malomba. Distribution patterns are given for these lakes, and, based on LM and SEM observations, an amended description of this taxon is presented. 10.2307/3668645|It is suggested that Euastrum species characterized by cells lacking a sharp apical incision and with broadly rounded lobes, capped with series of conical wall granules, are centred on Euastrum mononcylum. From this species, the other representatives of the group may be considered as being derived by reductions or elaborations in their morphology. Greatest species diversity is found in the tropics and especially tropical Africa. Most of the taxa under discussion seem to be confined to relatively small geographic regions, possibly related to failures in sexual reproduction, dispersal barriers, and their recent evolution. The relatively high percentage of endemic taxa, not only in the Euastrum group under discussion, but also in other genera, renders the desmids an algal group particularly susceptible to losses in biodiversity.
10.2307/3668642|Actinella comperei sp. nov. is described from Clarence Lagoon, an oligotrophic lake in the Tasmanian highlands (Australia). Its frustule morphology, as studied in light and scanning electron microscopy, is compared with that of other recently described Actinella species from Australasia. Actinella comperei differs from other Actinella species in valve shape, stria density and rimoportula arrangement. As most other species described from Australasia, A. comperei appears to be endemic to this region. 10.2307/3668654|The province North Brabant consists of 5083 km<sup>2</sup> between 40 m above and 1.5 m below sea level. Most of the land is in intensive agricultural use. Nature reserves consist of dune sands, heath, moorland pools and woods on very poor soils, bogs, low productive (wet) grasslands, stream valleys and a (former) estuary. There are 845 records of twenty charophyte species from 1986-1999. The majority of records were made in a small transition zone between the Pleistocene sand and loam area and the river and sea clay areas. Also the larger number of species (17) was found here. In the transition zone water quality varies considerably, due to the presence of seepage water of various age and origin. Some species are common to the Pleistocene area and the transition zone, others are common to the transition zone and both clay areas. At the loamy part of the Pleistocene area some species occur that grow in the transition zone and in the river clay area as well. In the dug off moor charophytes are only found at the edges of the area. In the former estuary, now a brackish lake, some species preferring slightly brackish to brackish water were found. Quite often charophytes are ephemeral, more so in shallow, eutrophic, and standing water, less so in opposite conditions. Charophytes are not protected by law. They may profit from conservation of rich sites and from nature improvement measures like digging pools for amphibians, restoration of moorland pools and removal of fertilised top soil. Charophytes may suffer from measures that have side effects such as reduction of surface water or deterioration of water quality.

20649772|Three new species of Commelina L. (Commelinaceae) are described from south-central Africa. Commelina sphaerorrhizoma Faden & Layton (D.R.Congo, Zambia, Angola) is distinguished by its moniliform rhizome composed of spherical segments, glaucous leaves that are glabrous above and often have cordate-amplexicaul bases, blue flowers and very large, hairy seeds. Its rhizome is similar only to those of the yellow-flowered Commelina crassicaulis C.B.Clarke and C. welwitschii C.B.Clarke, but its one-seeded capsule locules suggest a different, as yet obscure relationship. Commelina orchidophylla Faden & Layton (D.R.Congo) is distinguished by its tuberous roots, orchid-like pair of large basal leaves that are white-tomentose beneath and appressed to the ground, and free-margined spathes. It may be related to other geophytes or hemicryptophytes with free-margined spathes such as Commelina hockii De Wild., C. scaposa C.B.Clarke and C. psuedoscaposa De Wild., but differs from all of them by its large, distinctively pubescent basal leaves. Commelina rosulata Faden & Layton (D.R.Congo) is distinguished by its basal rosette of large, glabrous leaves and clustered, subglabrous spathes with fused margins. It may be most closely related to Commelina transversifolia De Wild., C. grossa C.B.Clarke and C. grandis Brenan, and may be separated from them by its large, broad basal leaves. Commelina praecox T.C.E.Fr. is a new synonym of C. scaposa C.B.Clarke and C. bianoensis De Wild. is a new synonym of Commelina neurophylla C.B.Clarke.

20649750|In order to compile a "Catalogue of neophytes in Belgium (1800-2005)" collections of vascular plants in the main Belgian herbaria (public as well as private) were thoroughly revised. This revision considerably enlarged the current knowledge of the alien flora of Belgium and yielded numerous additional taxa. On the other hand it has been shown that in the "Nouvelle Flore de la Belgique, du G.-D. de Luxembourg, du nord de la France et des rgions voisines" a number of non-native vascular plants have been erroneously or doubtfully listed as having occurred spontaneously in Belgium. The present paper provides information on 30 non-native taxa that need to be omitted from future editions of the Flora of Belgium due to reidentification of herbarium collections. Furthermore several dubious records of non-native plants in Belgium have never been confirmed by herbarium collections and are therefore doubtful; they are listed here but have been omitted from the "Catalogue." Finally, some non-native taxa included in the "Nouvelle Flore" have indeed been recorded for the neighbouring territories covered by this Flora, but never for Belgium and therefore they were omitted from the "Catalogue." The importance of a thorough herbarium revision as the main basis for the compilation of a catalogue of non-native plants (in stead of literature data) is stressed. Such a revision surely is more time-consuming but, above all, much more accurate and reliable. As such, it yielded 20% additional taxa in the final catalogue. Inversely, almost 3% of the taxa of the original list of Belgian xenophytes needed to be omitted.

10.2307/3668523|Plants grown in the tropical and subtropical greenhouses of the National Botanic Garden of Belgium (178 taxa belonging to 148 genera and 85 families) have been studied with regard to flowering and fruiting behaviour. The results are compared with other phenological data published in literature and with observations made on herbarium sheets at BR. Five types of behaviour are distinguished based on duration and frequency of flowering and fruiting periods. A calendar with the periods of maximum flowering is established. Flowering and fruiting periods are taken into account for their rhythm and are compared from year to year. Differences are related to the climatological data for the period studied or to the position of the plants in the greenhouses. A comparison of taxa of tropical and of subtropical origin shows that tropical taxa generally flower continuously or repeatedly while subtropical taxa have their main flowering period during the winter.

10.2307/3668605|The pollen dimorphism of eight African heterostylous species of Oxygonum Burch. ex Campd. is described for the first time using light and scanning electron microscopy. O. sinuatum shows the most pronounced pollen dimorphism with respect to size and exine ornamentation. There is, however, no significant difference in shape and in the number of apertures. Pollen polymorphism as a significant component of heterostyly and its functional significance and evolution are briefly discussed. Moreover, heterostyly is reported here in four additional species of Oxygonum, i.e., O. alatum, O. fruticosum, O. pachybasis and O. tenerum.

Anacampseros (A. angustifolium, A. densifolia, A. filamentosa, A. lanceolata, A. lanigera, A. rufescens, A. schoelandii, A. subnuda, A. telephiastrum, A. crinita) shows major similarities with Talinum regarding the ontogeny of the bracts, perianth and gynoecium: two involucral bracts are incepted successively; five tepals are initiated in a 2/5 phyllotaxis; generally, a three-carpellate syncarpous ovary develops. It is suggested that the first 'whorl', being homologous with the inner 'whorl' of Talinum and Portulaca undergoes a reduction of the stamen number, running concomitant with a centrifugal increase of the remaining stamens. Nectariferous tissue differentiates at the adaxial base of the androecium. It is concluded that the nectaries of Talinum and Anacampseros are homologous. On the basis of floral developmental patterns a close phylogenetic relation among Anacampseros, Talinum and Portulaca is confirmed.

10.2307/3668591|Plants of Galanthus nivalis L. and G. woronowii Losinsk. with additional inflorescences or additional green leaves were selected for analysis. A formal method of interpretation has been developed. 1. Organs were positioned on diagrams. 2. Diagrams were transformed into axial schemes. Both monopodial and sympodial models were assumed to be equally valid. If necessary for the phyllotaxis correction, the phantom leaves were included in the interpretation. 3. Schemes were sub-divided into monopodial and sympodial groups. 4. Schemes, containing a minimum of phantoms, were compared by superposition. 10.2307/3668597|From about 1993 to the present (1998), millions of plants of Fargesia murieliae, an ornamental bamboo, were flowering monocarpically in western Europe. All plants being ramets of a single genet, introduced in Europe about 80 years ago, the simultaneous flowering of all these ramets constitutes a single giant compound inflorescence. Flowering plants were subjected to different conditions of light intensity and temperature yielding different modes of development of flowering. Under low light intensity and high ambient temperatures (22-25C), reversion of flowering is ultimately observed by development of vegetative shoots from basal buds of flowering culms. Under conditions that induce oxidative stress (full sun and drought) flowering and senescence proceed rapidly. The process of senescence is linked to oxidative stress as measured in elevated activities of superoxide dismutase and ascorbate peroxidase in the semelauctant inflorescences. By strong photoreduction of catalase activity, high light intensity is directly responsible for inactivation of one of the major defence mechanisms of the cells, thereby effectively accelerating flowering and senescence. In blades of spathes subtending the semelauctant inflorescences (short paracladial zone), DNA replication as well as loss of DNA from nuclei is observed. As this phenomenon is observed in green spathes prior to the development of the terminal inflorescence, DNA replication is a very early marker for senescence. A role for extra DNA synthesis prior to senescence is suggested in cytokinin biosynthesis.

10.2307/3668598|A survey of inflorescence morphology was conducted as part of a phylogenetic analysis of the Aristolochiaceae. The two members of the subfamily Asaroideae, Saruma and Asarum, have monotelic inflorescences and sympodial growth. In contrast, polytelic inflorescences are the rule within the subfamily Aristolochioideae, where two types of synflorescences occur: thyrsic (if cymose partial florescences are present), and racemose (if only one ebracteate flower is formed at each node). The partial florescence (PF) is used to compare the taxa within the subfamily. Many-flowered PFs are common in most members of Aristolochia, although 1-flowered PFs occur in all species of A. subsect. Pentandrae, as well as in some members of A. subgen. Siphisia, A. sect. Diplolobus, and A. subsect. Hexandrae. Two types of racemose synflorescences are recognized: frondose (or frondulose) synflorescences, in A. rojasiana (formerly Euglypha) and A. subser. Hexandrae; and rami- or cauliflorous coflorescences (i.e. lateral racemes), in A. reniformis (formerly Holostylis) and A. subser. Anthocaulicae. Cauliflory appears to be independently acquired in different members of the Aristolochioideae. Two different structural (and perhaps functional) types of cauliflory are described: the first occurs when a cymose, often densiflorous, PF, develops late (in members of Thottea, Aristolochia subgen. Siphisia, A. subgen. Pararistolochia, and A. ser. Thyrsicae), and the second when flowering occurs exclusively in short, bracteose lateral racemes (in A. subsect. Anthocaulicae). Characters related to the position and structure of the PF and the specialization of lateral racemes for flowering were found to be informative for a preliminary phylogenetic analysis (Gonzlez 1997). The analysis generated a hypothesis of a transformation from thyrsic to racemose synflorescences, via a reduction in the number of flowers to one on each PF and the loss of the bract. Other derived characters are the frondulose or bracteose pherophylls, and the strictly lateral position of the coflorescences.
10.2307/3668595|Wood anatomy of 16 genera of the Pavetteae has been examined. Special attention was given to the morphology of vestures associated with vessel pits and two vesture types were defined. 10.2307/3668586|Evolutionary biology of flowers has undergone a revolution in the past twenty years. It began with the recovery of excellently preserved Cretaceous fossil flowers and was followed by the improvement of molecular techniques and their application in developmental genetics and systematics, which opened new avenues for evolutionary flower research. In turn, these new fields stimulated comparative floral studies, and traditional approaches in concert with the new ones are now greatly needed. Wilhelm Troll (1897-1978) was a prominent and influential plant morphologist of this century. He and his students were responsible for great advancements in comparative morphological (including floral) studies, although this did not include the addressing of evolutionary questions, since the foundations to understand bauplan evolution were not present at his time.

10.2307/3668587|Scientific terms should denote similar, comparable, or at the best homologous structures. At the onset of botanical terminology there was often only a very superficial similarity between objects for which the same name was used. Thus, the term "seed" was used for everything that produced a new plant (with the exception of suckers and the like). Later on the term "spore" was introduced by Ehrhart (1778), and in the course of time the differences between seed and spore were better understood. The term spore was first used in a very broad sense, too. It had to be clarified by the exclusion of gametes and zygotes and by the distinction of meio- and mitospores. Several botanical terms that point to analogous rather than homologous structures have been used for a long time. The German term "Eichen" (small egg) for "ovulum" was replaced by "Samenknospe" (seed bud) and finally by "Samenanlage" when it became clear that it was neither an egg nor a small bud. However, the term ovule was kept in English and French. According to the classical morphological view of Goethe (1790), the stamens are named "Staubbltter" and the carpels "Fruchtbltter" in German. No comparable terms exist in English or French. Several other examples are given in order to illustrate the complex connections between terminology and homology in describing and interpreting plant structures.
10.2307/3668585|As a result of his extensive work as botanist and morphologist Wilhelm Troll acquired a worldwide reputation. His scientific research and his activities as an academic teacher influenced not only morphology but also had marked effects on the development of other fields of botanic research, of biology and even beyond biology.

10.2307/3668588|Two exemplary case studies of functional morphology are presented. The first topic, underground plant mobility, illustrates the feedback effect of 'plant structure' and observation of their 'functional role'. Questions are raised in relation to both, 'plant structure' and its 'functional role'. Experiments are developed to obtain answers, and to prompt further questions resulting from these answers. This was shown in an exemplary way in the unusually geophilous strategies of Hemerocallis fulva, well adapted to fulfilling the function 'cryptical survival'. Thus, investigation of functional morphology is useful for a better understanding of plant behaviour. The second case study relates to dispersal of diaspores in Apiaceae. Wind tunnel experiments were carried out to analyze the 'flying ability' of winged or spiny mericarps. In general, winged diaspores fly better than spiny ones, except in the case of Daucus muricatus, the spiny diaspores of which fly better than the winged ones, e.g., of Prangos pabularia. Thus, this topic was useful in showing that functional approaches to 'plant structure' may reveal new perspectives in ecological understanding. However, 'form' and 'function' are frequent in botanical literature, showing that a dualistic treatment of plant structures is very helpful for a better understanding of plant biology. Besides 'underground plant movement' and 'dispersal' there are important topics such as 'floral ecology', 'biomechanics', and many more. All of these could be included in one category, which we propose to call 'plant construction'. Scientific work on 'plant construction' should be based on three basic principles: 1. The starting point of the investigation should be the specific form itself, 2. The scientific question should be functional, and 3. Scientific investigation should be based on targeted observation and experiment.
10.2307/3668601|A study on four species of the genus Phacelia (Hydrophyllaceae) was focused on flower and fruit development. A combination of morphological characters of the corolla and the gynoecium (including formation and distribution of crystals) is shown to be useful in segregating even closely related taxa within the genus. Half inferior ovaries, as demonstrated for two species, seem to be more frequent within the genus than previously assumed. Corresponding stages during early gynoecium development and characters of the nectary disc and corolla may underline a closer relationship between Hydrophyllaceae and Boraginaceae.
10.2307/3668594|In adult woody plants, there is a division of labour between innovation and reproduction: One particular group of meristems, buds or shoot sections guarantees the vegetative continuation, another one only functions for a short period of pollination or diaspore production. The reproductive elements originate from the purely vegetative shoot sections by different ways of segregation. The unit of extension (UE) is used as the reference matrix to describe different types of allocation: (1) terminal flowering in competition with the vegetative apex, (2) lateral inflorescence shoots occupying a vacant UE section, (3) "mixed" structure of 1 and 2, (4) partial or full displacement of strong lateral shoots, (5) accessory buds developing into both vegetative and reproductive organs, (6) long-term reproductive capacity by accessory or prophyll shoots which is widespread in tropical families, (7) alternation between a reproductive and a non-reproductive UE form, (8) insertion of an additional short-shoot-like reproductive UE. Also a change of arrangement is possible because the UE programme undergoes a regressive metamorphosis during tree ageing or at subordinate branches. At the branch level, the allocation is described by the "shoot chain" in terms of monopodial, ananthic-sympodial or anthetic-sympodial. Research is based upon temperate species but the results can be extrapolated to some tropical species.
10.2307/3668604|The effect of irrigation and artificial nutrient supply on nectar secretion and nectary structure of three of the main Labiatae species occurring in a phryganic community (viz. Satureja thymbra, Stachys cretica, and Thymus capitatus) was studied. Experiments were carried out on potted plants taken from the wild, along with control plants (untreated or/and naturally growing). Only T. capitatus clearly secreted a higher nectar volume and sugars after treatment, whereas the yield of S. thymbra did not increase significantly when plants were irrigated or artificially supplied with nutrients. The case of S. cretica was more complicated showing different trends depending on the time of the year. Conclusions are: (i) nutrient supply does not always enhance nectar secretion in the poor-soil phrygana; (ii) irrigation is more important in increasing per flower nectar secretion than fertilization; (iii) nutrient supply results in the presence of nectarless flowers; (iv) nectar analyses made on three plants show that neither of the treatments affects amino acid concentration of the nectar, but they result in either glucose excess in the nectar of woody species (viz. S. thymbra, T. capitatus) or in sucrose excess in the nectar of herbaceous species (S. cretica). Most of these results can be explained through a differential resource allocation of the water-stressed plants grown in the wild on the one hand, and the treated plants on the other. This difference stems from the fact that woody species clearly distinguish between growth and reproductive phases, whereas in herbaceous perennials the growing phase overlaps with reproductive phase and blooming. Under conditions of artificial nutrient supply, plants may continue to allocate to vegetative growth rather than to pollinator allurement; on the contrary, wild growing plants may invest exclusively in pollinator allurement. It is assumed that the approach of the summer is very critical and conclusive for a shorter life cycle of the species. Some intraspecific differences in nectary structure were found as a result of the treatments. However, because these differences were not consistent either with the treatment effects on nectar secretion or with the nectar characteristics studied, it is concluded that the observed differences may be mere intraspecific variations normally occurring in nature.

3668767|Relationships among 111 species of the Psychotria complex (Rubiaceae tribe Psychotrieae) were estimated by cladistic analysis of nucleotide sequence variation in the rps16 intron (cpDNA). The Psychotria complex is characterised morphologically by caducous stipules and (usually) testa with a reddish, ethanol soluble pigment. It was found to be comprised of two major clades, one of which is Psychotria in a strict sense. Psychotria s. str. is characterised by usually having pyrenes without preformed germination slits, a plane or shallowly furrowed adaxial surface and usually numerous distinct ridges on the abaxial side. Most species occur in Africa and the Neotropics, but the genus extends eastwards to the Philippines and Australia. The second subclade comprises species from areas around the Indian Ocean and in the Pacific. Members of this subclade mostly differ morphologically from Psychotria s. str. by pyrenes with distinct marginal preformed germination slits. This subclade includes the tuberiferous, myrmecophile epiphytes, which, it is suggested, comprise a single genus, Hydnophytum. It also includes the genera Amaracarpus, Calycosia, Dolianthus, and Straussia. These genera are not supported as monophyletic by sequence data, but are tentatively recognized based on morphological evidence. Calycosia should be given a broader circumscription than presently and may be characterised by entire endosperm and pollen grains with usually thin exine and small lumina. The name Straussia has traditionally been applied only to Hawaiian species, but is applicable to a more widely distributed group. Its major distinguishing feature is a more or less ruminate endosperm.

3668627|This first-ever revision of Chione DC. (Rubiaceae), a genus of neotropical trees and shrubs, is based on the study of herbarium specimens and field observations. Chione can be diagnosed by a combination of characters, some of which are: entire and caducous interpetiolar stipules, terminal inflorescences that turn white or greenish-white when mature, funnelform corollas with strongly recurved lobes, corolla lobes imbricate in bud, anthers inserted near the base of the corolla tube, fruits maturing red to purple, each fruit with a single, sclerenchymatized pyrene enclosing two locules, and ovules that are solitary and pendulous in locules. C. venosa var. cubensis (distributed in Cuba and Hispaniola) and var. mexicana (distributed in eastern Mexico) are distinguished from the other varieties by having relatively small fruits and smooth pyrenes. C. venosa var. cubensis is distinguished from var. mexicana by typically having thicker leaves and longer corolla lobes relative to corolla tube length. C. venosa var. buxifolia (known only from the immediate vicinity of Cerro Jefe, Panama) is distinguished from var. venosa (distributed from Tamaulipas, Mexico to Junn, Peru, and from the Dominican Republic to Tobago) by its extremely reduced and coriaceous leaves.
